THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Social Services, County of Siskiyou, and Debra J. Little, Plaintiffs, Of whom, S.C. Department of Social Services is, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Michael D. Martin, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS 

Appeal From Greenwood County
Â Billy A. Tunstall, Jr., Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 26218
Heard September 20, 2006 - Filed November 6, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        C. Rauch Wise, of Greenwood; and Billy J. Garrett, Jr., of The Garrett Law Firm, of Greenwood, for Petitioner.
        Holly C. Walker, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


Justice Burnett:Â  The family court issued a civil contempt order against Michael D. Martin (Petitioner) for failure to pay child support pursuant to a California support order.Â  Petitioner filed a motion for reconsideration and the family court vacated its order.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Petitioner and Debra J. Little divorced in Siskiyou County, California.Â  The California Superior Court issued a divorce decree in 1986, granting custody of the coupleâ€™s daughter to Little and custody of the coupleâ€™s son to Petitioner.Â  The court also issued a child support order (the 1986 California order), requiring Petitioner to pay $303.00 per month for the support of his daughter.Â  Thereafter, Petitioner moved to South Carolina and established his residence in Greenwood County. 
In 1989, Siskiyou County and Little filed a summons and complaint in Greenwood County accompanied by a support petition pursuant to the Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act (URESA), S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-960 to -1170 (1985). Â The petition sought support in the amount of $326.00 per month, as well as medical coverage and arrearages.Â  A copy of the 1986 California order was attached to the petition.Â  
Prior to the hearing, the parties reached an agreement which was incorporated into an order issued by the family court in 1990 (the 1990 South Carolina order).Â  The 1990 South Carolina order required Petitioner to pay $30 per week for support of the coupleâ€™s daughter and $10 per week toward the arrearage.Â  It referred to the prior California order but did not explicitly nullify it.Â  
In 2003, the family court found Petitioner in civil contempt for failure to pay support under the 1986 California order.Â  Petitioner filed a motion for temporary relief asking the family court to stay prospective child support.Â  South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) argued that Petitioner was responsible for the arrearage under the 1986 California order because that order had not been extinguished by the 1990 South Carolina order.Â  Petitioner argued that the 1990 order modified the 1986 California order.Â  Because that agreement was not appealed, Petitioner argued that the 1990 South Carolina order became the law of the case.Â  Â Â 
The family court vacated its prior civil contempt order and held it did not have legal authority to overrule the final order of another family court judge.Â  The family court determined it would not have issued the civil contempt order had it been aware of the 1990 South Carolina order. 
DSS appealed the matter and the Court of Appeals reversed.Â  The Court of Appeals held the family court erroneously determined the 1990 South Carolina order was final and terminated Petitionerâ€™s prospective California support obligations.Â  Applying URESA, the Court of Appeals determined the family court had authority to modify and enforce the 1986 California order based on S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-933 (Supp. 2003), which provides the family court has â€œthe right to modify any such decree, judgment, or order for child support as the court considers necessary upon a showing of changed circumstances.â€ 
The Court of Appeals also relied on what is commonly known as the anti-nullification clause found in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1110 (1985) (amended 1994): â€œA support order made by a court of this State pursuant to this subarticle does not nullify and is not nullified by â€¦ a support order made by a court of any other state â€¦ unless otherwise specifically provided by the court.â€Â  The Court of Appeals held that the 1986 California order remained independently enforceable in South Carolina because the 1990 South Carolina order did not indicate it was intended to nullify the California order.Â  
ISSUE
Did the Court of Appeals err in holding the 1990 South Carolina order did not nullify the 1986 California order? 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, this Court has the authority to correct errors of law and find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415 S.E.2d 812, 814 (1992).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require this Court to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005).Â  Questions concerning child support are ordinarily committed to the discretion of the family court, whose conclusions will not be disturbed on appeal absent a showing of an abuse of discretion.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 282, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002); Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70, 73, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 2003). Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The applicable law governing the case is URESA, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-960 to 1170 (1985).[1]Â  The purpose of URESA is to â€œimprove and extend by reciprocal legislation the enforcement of duties of support.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-965 (1985).Â  Section 20-7-933 (Supp. 2005) gives courts the authority to enforce orders regarding child support and the right to modify support orders upon a showing of changed circumstances.Â  See, e.g., Balestrine v. Jordan, 275 S.C. 442, 443, 272 S.E.2d 438 (1980) (â€œA decree of support may be increased, decreased or terminated due to a change in circumstances â€¦.â€).Â  URESA allows orders issued in other states to be registered and enforced in South Carolina as if issued by a court of this State.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1150 & -1155 (1985).Â  URESA remedies â€œare in addition to and not in substitution for any other remedies.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-975 (1985).
Petitioner argues the 1990 South Carolina order modified the 1986 California order such that it extinguished his obligations under the prior order.Â  We disagree.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In Carswell, the Court of Appeals held that a Washington support order remained extant and enforceable when South Carolina support orders recognized but did not specifically nullify the Washington order.Â  SCDSS/Child Support Enforcement v. Carswell, 359 S.C. 425, 430, 597 S.E.2d 859, 861 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  After Carswell moved to South Carolina from Washington, the family court modified the amount of support due under a Washington support order but never explicitly nullified the Washington order. Â Id. at 427, 597 S.E.2d at 860.Â  Thereafter, DSS sought registration and enforcement of the Washington order in South Carolina pursuant to URESA.Â  Id.Â  The family court refused to enforce the Washington order and held that it had been modified by the South Carolina orders such that only one support order continued to exist.Â  Id.Â  Relying on Section 20-7-1110, the anti-nullification provision, the Court of Appeals reversed and held that both the original Washington order and subsequent South Carolina orders remained enforceable.Â  Id. at 429-430, 597 S.E.2d at 861.Â  Because the South Carolina orders merely recognized the Washington order, the orders did not rise to the level of a nullification and the Washington order remained valid and enforceable in South Carolina.Â  Id.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In the instant case, the 1990 South Carolina order referenced the prior California order, but never explicitly nullified it.Â  Like the order in Carswell, the 1990 South Carolina order did not rise to the level of nullification.Â  Therefore, both the 1986 California order and the 1990 South Carolina order are independently enforceable. See also Hamlett, 330 S.C. at 326, 498 S.E.2d at 890-891 (â€œ[A] South Carolina support order continues as an independently enforceable order regardless of its registration and modification in a foreign state unless specifically nullified by the court pursuant to section 20-7-1110 [the anti-nullification clause].â€). Â Â Â Â 
Petitioner argues the unappealed order from 1990 became the law of the case and the parties improperly â€œrelitigatedâ€ the 1990 order in 2003.Â  Petitionerâ€™s argument is without merit.Â  The 2003 litigation concerned the 1986 California order which remained independently enforceable because the 1990 South Carolina order did not nullify it.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the Court of Appeals.Â  The 1990 South Carolina order did not nullify the 1986 California order.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Â In 1994, URESA was replaced by the Uniform Interstate Family Support Act (UIFSA), S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-960 to 1170 (Supp. 2005).Â  URESA continues to apply, however, to the enforcement of rights, liabilities, duties, and forfeitures as they stood prior to 1994 under URESA.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Hamlett, 330 S.C. 321, 498 S.E.2d 888 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The initial support obligation in this action arose in 1986, so URESA is controlling.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Interest of Amir X. S., a juvenile under the age of seventeen, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenwood County
Â John M. Rucker, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 26219
Heard September 20, 2006 - Filed November 6, 2006Â Â  

AFFIRMED IN PART; VACATED IN PART


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Jerry W. Peace, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

___________
CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â Â Â  This case involves a constitutional attack on a statute defining the offense of disturbing schools.Â  The family court upheld the statuteâ€™s constitutionality and subsequently adjudicated Appellant delinquent for violating the statute.Â  We affirm in part and vacate in part.
Factual/Procedural Background
The State filed a juvenile petition in family court in October 2004 alleging that Amir X. S. (â€œAppellantâ€) violated S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-420 (2003) by willfully, unlawfully, and unnecessarily interfering with and disturbing the students and teachers at Southside Learning Center in Greenwood County, South Carolina.Â Â Â  
Before trial, Appellant moved to quash the juvenile petition claiming that Â§ 16-17-420 was unconstitutionally vague and overbroad in violation of the First Amendment of the United States Constitution.Â  Section 16-17-420 provides in pertinent part:

  It shall be unlawful:Â  (1) For any person wilfully or unnecessarily (a) to interfere with or to disturb in any way or in any place the students or teachers of any school or college in this State, (b) to loiter about such school or college premises or (c) to act in an obnoxious manner thereon . . . .â€Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-420(1).
At the hearing on Appellantâ€™s motion to quash, the State argued Appellant lacked standing to challenge the statuteâ€™s constitutionality because Appellantâ€™s conduct plainly fell under its terms.Â  The family court upheld the constitutionality of the statute and denied Appellantâ€™s motion.Â  After hearing testimony from each party, the family court found there was sufficient evidence to adjudicate Appellant delinquent for the violation of Â§ 16-17-420.Â  The family court committed Appellant to ninety days in the custody of the Department of Juvenile Justice and imposed one year of probation. 
Appellant filed this appeal pursuant to Rule 203, SCACR[1] and raises the following issues for review:

  
    I.  
    Is § 16-17-420 unconstitutional because it is overly broad and punishes a substantial amount of protected free speech in relation to the statute’s plainly legitimate sweep?
  
  
    II. 
    Does Appellant have standing to challenge § 16-17-420 on grounds of vagueness; and if so, is the statute unconstitutional because it is written in terms so vague that a person of common intelligence must necessarily guess at its meaning?
  

Law/Analysis
I. Overbreadth
Appellant argues that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-420 is unconstitutional because it is overly broad and punishes a substantial amount of protected free speech in relation to the statuteâ€™s plainly legitimate sweep.Â  We disagree.
The First Amendment overbreadth doctrine is an exception to the usual rules regarding the standards for facial challenges.Â  First, because the very existence of overly broad statutes may have such a deterrent effect on constitutionally protected expression, the traditional rule of standing[2] is relaxed for facial[3] overbreadth claims involving First Amendment rights.Â  Broadrick v. Oklahoma, 413 U.S. 601, 612 (1973).Â Â  Â Â Â Under this relaxed rule of standing, the party challenging a statute simply must demonstrate that the statute could cause someone else - anyone else - to refrain from constitutionally protected expression.Â Â  Dombrowski v. Pfister, 380 U.S. 479, 486 (1965). Â Â In further recognition of the threat to First Amendment freedoms, any enforcement of a statute subject to an overbreadth claim is wholly forbidden until and unless a limiting construction or partial invalidation so narrows it so as to remove the seeming threat to protected expression.Â  Broadrick, 413 U.S. at 613.Â  These exceptions to the traditional rules of practice have been implemented out of concern that the threat of enforcement of an overly broad law may deter or â€œchillâ€ constitutionally protected speech - especially when the overly broad law imposes criminal sanctions.Â  Virginia v. Hicks, 539 U.S. 113, 119 (2003).
In light of these exceptions to the traditional rules of practice, courts have been â€œsensitive to the risk that the doctrine itself might sweep so broadly that the exception to ordinary standing requirements would swallow the general rule.â€ Â Members of the City Council of the City of Los Angeles v. Â Taxpayers for Vincent, 466 U.S. 789, 799 (1984).Â  In developing the overbreadth doctrine, the United States Supreme Court has cautioned: 

  . . . its function, a limited one at the outset, attenuates as the otherwise unprotected behavior that it forbids the State to sanction moves from â€œpure speechâ€ toward conduct[,] and that conduct - even if expressive - falls within the scope of otherwise valid criminal laws that reflect legitimate state interests in maintaining comprehensive controls over harmful, constitutionally unprotected conduct.

Broadrick, 413 U.S. at 615.Â  
In an effort to balance these varying interests, courts require that the alleged First Amendment overbreadth must not only be real, but also â€œsubstantialâ€ in order to apply the overbreadth exception in a particular case.Â  Taxpayers for Vincent, 466 U.S. at 799-800 (quoting Broadrick, 413 U.S. at 615).Â  Therefore, the doctrine of overbreadth permits a court to wholly invalidate a statute only when the terms are so broad that they punish a substantial amount of protected free speech in relation to the statuteâ€™s otherwise plainly legitimate sweep - until and unless a limiting construction or partial invalidation narrows it so as to remove the threat or deterrence to constitutionally protected expression.Â  Hicks, 539 U.S. at 118-119.
Turning to the instant case, we first note that although conduct generally is not protected by the First Amendment, expressive conduct may be.Â  U.S. v. Oâ€™Brien, 391 U.S. 367, 376 (1968).Â  However, we do not find that Â§ 16-17-420 prohibits the kind of clearly expressive conduct historically subject to overbreadth adjudication in the school context.Â  Notably, in Tinker v. Des Moines Independent Community School District, 393 U.S. 503 (1969), the United States Supreme Court declared unconstitutional a school boardâ€™s actions suspending students for wearing black armbands to school in protest of the Vietnam War.Â  In Tinker, the court held that wearing armbands as a â€œsilent, passive expression of opinionâ€ was protected symbolic speech regardless of the popularity of the opinion being expressed.Â  Restricting this type of speech when it was â€œunaccompanied by any disorder or disturbanceâ€ could not be tolerated under the First Amendment.Â  393 U.S. at 508.Â  Prior to that, in Edwards v. South Carolina, 372 U.S. 229 (1963), the United States Supreme Court held that breach of the peace convictions for high school and college students peaceably assembling and protesting on public grounds were unconstitutional as violative of the First Amendment.Â  
An analysis of Â§ 16-17-420 is more appropriately derived from cases analyzing statutes targeting conduct termed â€œdisruptiveâ€ to schools, with no specific prohibition otherwise on First Amendment expressive conduct.Â  Grayned v. City of Rockford, 408 U.S. 104 (1972) is the leading United States Supreme Court decision in that context.Â  In Grayned, the petitioner was convicted under an Illinois antinoise ordinance for his part in a demonstration in front of a school.Â  He subsequently challenged the constitutionality of the ordinance which prohibited â€œany noise or diversion which disturbs or tends to disturb the peace or good order of a schoolâ€ on grounds of vagueness and overbreadth.Â  408 U.S. at 108.Â  Relying on Tinker as its touchstone, the court held that although the statute tended to target expressive conduct, such expressive conduct could be restricted in the school environment if the forbidden conduct â€œmaterially disrupts classwork or involves substantial disorder or invasion of the rights of others.â€Â  Id. at 118 (quoting Tinker, 393 U.S. at 513).Â  The court distinguished the demonstration at issue in Grayned from the wearing of armbands in Tinker primarily on the grounds that the Tinker students â€œneither interrupted school activities nor sought to intrude in the school affairs or the lives of others.â€Â  Id. (quoting Tinker, 393 U.S. at 514).Â  It further noted the limited scope of the ordinance, which it construed to punish only conduct that disrupted normal school activities - a decision necessarily made on a case-by-case basis.Â  Id. at 119.Â  The Grayned court concluded by saying that the cityâ€™s â€œmodest restriction on some peaceful picketing represents a considered and specific legislative judgment that some kinds of expressive activity should be restricted at a particular time and place, here in order to protect the schools.â€Â  Id. at 121.Â  Such a reasonable regulation, it held, was consistent with the First Amendment and therefore the antinoise ordinance was not invalid on its face.Â  Id. at 121.
More analogous to the case before this Court is McAlpine v. Reese, 305 F. Supp. 136 (1970), in which the federal district court in Michigan upheld the constitutionality of a Michigan ordinance similar to Â§ 16-17-420 against facial attacks of vagueness and overbreadth. The Michigan ordinance at issue provided:Â  

  No person shall wilfully or maliciously make or assist in making any noise, disturbance, or improper diversion by which the peace, quietude or good order of any public, private, or parochial school is disturbed.Â  

305 F. Supp. at 138 (citing Detroit Muni. Code, Â§ 39-1-57 (1954)).Â  In McAlpine, the district court observed that the ordinance did not by its terms â€œprohibit any kind of gathering or expression save that which disturbs the quietude of a school.â€Â  Id. at 140.Â  The court noted the â€œfundamental interest to our society . . . [of] the schools and their undisturbed operationâ€ and determined that the only kind of conduct prohibited by the ordinance was not â€œfree speechâ€ but rather â€œfree abuse of others.â€Â  Id. at 141.Â Â  Ultimately, the court rendered the ordinance unsuitable for overbreadth invalidation by concluding that the type of conduct prohibited could â€œnot be tolerated in any ordered society.â€Â  Id.Â  The fact that free speech was intermingled with such conduct did not automatically call for constitutional protection. Id. (quoting Cox v. Louisiana, 379 U.S. 559, 564 (1965).Â  At the same time, the McAlpine court, like the Grayned court, was careful in its opinion to distinguish the scope of the Michigan ordinance from other prohibitions on expression that did not involve the disruption of schools, reiterating that the latter would be subject to constitutional protection.Â Â  Id.
Similarly, in S.H. B. v. State of Florida, 355 So.2d 1176 (Fla. 1977), the Florida Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of a statute prohibiting the willful interruption or disturbance of â€œany school.â€Â  Fla. Stat. Â§ 871.01 (1973).Â  The plaintiff, convicted under the statute for behavior that included â€œrunning through the halls of a school in session, disobeying the lawful and reasonable requests of school officials, and repeated loud utterances,â€ claimed the statute was overly broad on its face.Â  S.H.B., 355 So.2d at 1179.Â Â  He asserted that an overbreadth analysis of the statute should be governed by cases defining the constitutional limits of breach of the peace statutes.Â  The Florida court disagreed and held that the statute at issue only prohibited disturbances of lawful assembly (i.e. school gatherings) and therefore was limited in its application in a way that breach of the peace statutes were not.Â  Id. at 1178.Â  The court recognized that school gatherings are â€œfragile by their nature,â€ id., and comparing the school environment to a general public forum, the court noted that in schools, â€œa single individual may cause havoc in a situation in which hundreds of others have sought a common purpose.â€Â  Id.Â  The court emphasized that certain conduct - even if â€œexpressiveâ€ - could disrupt the school environment even where it might not elsewhere.Â  Id.Â  The Florida court, like the Grayned court, condoned a case-by-case approach to weeding out overly broad applications of the statute and held that the statute was constitutional on its face.Â  Id.Â  
Applying these principles to South Carolinaâ€™s disturbing schools statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-420(1), we find that it does not substantially prohibit First Amendment speech.Â  By its terms, the statute does not apply to protected speech.Â  Specifically, the disturbing schools statute does not prohibit spoken words or conduct â€œakin to â€˜pure speech.â€™â€ Â Tinker, 393 U.S. at 508.Â  Nor does the statute broadly regulate conduct like a breach of the peace statute.[4]Â Â  Broadrick, 413 U.S. at 616.Â  Instead, Â§ 16-17-420 criminalizes conduct that â€œdisturbsâ€ or â€œinterferesâ€ with schools, or is â€œobnoxious.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-420(1)(a) and (c).Â  In applying the Tinker distinction between direct restrictions on silent, passive expression of opinion versus restrictions on expression when accompanied by disorder or disturbance of schools, Â§ 16-17-420, like the regulations at issue in McAlpine and S.H.B., clearly applies to the latter.Â  Such conduct is not protected by the First Amendment and accordingly, we hold that Â§ 16-17-420 is not a substantial threat to protected speech requiring overbreadth adjudication.Â  
The overbreadth doctrine additionally provides that any threat or deterrence to constitutionally protected expression may be removed by a limiting construction on the challenged statute.Â Â  Broadrick, 413 U.S. at 613.Â  Analyzed from this perspective, Â§ 16-17-420 is limited in its application by its own terms so as to remove any substantial threat to constitutionally protected expression. First, the statute specifically deals with the disturbance of students and teachers in South Carolinaâ€™s schools, and not a disturbance in just any public forum.Â  See S.H.B., 355 So.2d at 1178.Â  Furthermore, it does not explicitly prohibit any type of gathering or expression except those which disturb the learning environment in South Carolinaâ€™s schools.Â  Those who wish to engage in this type of â€œexpressionâ€ are free to either do so elsewhere; or do so in the school environment in a way that does not disturb schools.Â  McAlpine, 309 F. Supp. at 140.Â  Finally, the statute is limited in the type of conduct that may be punished.Â  The disturbance or interference is required to be done â€œwilfullyâ€ or â€œunnecessarily.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-420(1)(a).Â  
Taken to its outermost First Amendment boundaries, Â§ 16-17-420 is most accurately characterized as â€œintertwiningâ€ speech and non-speech elements.Â  Cox v. Louisiana, 379 U.S. at 563; McAlpine, 309 F. Supp at 140.Â  Â Â Appellant argues that this might include constitutionally protected expression, but we find this is not â€œsubstantiallyâ€ so.Â  The proper functioning of schools is â€œa topic of great and fundamental interest to our society.â€Â  McAlpine 309 F. Supp. at 140.Â  Clearly the State has a legitimate interest in maintaining the integrity of its education system.[5]Â  This objective is necessarily achieved in part by classroom discipline.Â  Because the school environment is â€œfragile by [its] nature,â€ it requires a certain level of conduct and cooperation on the part of both the student and the teacher in order to function effectively for all its participants.Â  S.H.B., 355 So.2d at 1178.Â  Any conduct in this context that interferes with the Stateâ€™s legitimate objectives may be prohibited.Â  â€œThe fact that free speech is intermingled with such conduct does not bring with it constitutional protection.â€Â  McAlpine, 309 F. Supp. at 140.Â Â  
Appellant urges this Court to consider a school debate scenario where an individual could be prosecuted under Â§ 16-17-420 for expressing a â€œdisturbingâ€ view, which in turn might implicate other students who openly disagree with that view in a manner deemed â€œobnoxious.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-420(1).Â  The innocent scenario suggested by Appellant is clearly not within the scope of Â§ 16-17-420, nor would this Court construe it that way.Â  Tinker permits the State to enforce its significant interest in its education system by punishing behavior that â€œmaterially disrupts classwork or involves substantial disorder or invasion of the rights of others.â€Â  393 U.S. at 506.Â Â  Section 16-17-420 prohibits no more than this.Â  Moreover, the United States Supreme Court has mandated a case-by-case approach to address whatever overbreadth may exist.Â  See Grayned, 408 U.S. at 119-120; Broadrick, 413 U.S. at 615. Â Â See also S.H.B., 355 So.2d at 1178.Â  A case-by-case approach to the enforcement of the statute allows this Court to act accordingly in the unlikely event that a person genuinely exercising his constitutional right to expression - such as the debate team member envisioned by Appellant - becomes a target of Â§ 16-17-420.Â  See S.H.B., 355 So.2d at 1178; McAlpine, 309 F. Supp. at 141.
Any fertile legal imagination can dream up conceivable ways in which enforcement of a statute violates First Amendment rights.Â  Grayned, 408 U.S. at 111, n. 15.Â  However, conceivable overbreadth must be substantial in order to merit overbreadth adjudication.Â  Notwithstanding all other laws of this state, Appellant and others are welcome to express themselves in a way that â€œdisturbsâ€ others in any other public forum without offending Â§ 16-17-420.Â  Because of the stateâ€™s fundamental interest in protecting its schools, Â§ 16-17-420 draws the line on conduct that materially disturbs normal school activity - the very same constitutional line drawn by Tinker and its progeny.Â  We therefore hold that Â§ 16-17-420 does not punish a substantial amount of protected speech, and accordingly, does not warrant overbreadth adjudication.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â  Vagueness
Respondent contends that Appellant lacks standing to make a facial vagueness challenge to the constitutionality of Â§ 16-17-420.Â Â  We agree.
The traditional rule of standing for facial attacks on statutes, supra n.3, applies to facial vagueness challenges such as the one before this Court.Â  â€œThe concept of vagueness or indefiniteness rests on the constitutional principle that procedural due process requires fair notice and proper standards for adjudication.â€ State v. Michau, 355 S.C. 73, 76, 583 S.E.2d 756, 758 (2003) (quoting Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 571, 549 S.E.2d 591, 598 (2001)).Â  The constitutional standard for vagueness is whether the law gives fair notice to those persons to whom the law applies. Therefore, â€œone to whose conduct the law clearly applies does not have standing to challenge it for vaguenessâ€ as applied to the conduct of others.Â  Village of Hoffman Estates, 455 U.S. at 495; Michau, 355 S.C. at 77, 583 S.E.2d at 758.
There can be no doubt that Appellantâ€™s conduct falls within the most narrow application of Â§ 16-17-420.Â  Appellantâ€™s teacher testified to the family court that for a period of over two hours, Appellant behaved in a way that was wilfully disruptive and unnecessary.Â  Appellant paced about the classroom and refused to remain in his desk; cursed to his teacher and other students; and harassed one student with comments about the studentâ€™s mother.Â  For over two hours, Appellantâ€™s teacher patiently attempted to reason with him regarding his classroom behavior, to no avail.Â  Left with no other choice but to remove Appellant from the classroom so that she and the other students could focus on their educational objectives, the teacher asked another staff member to escort Appellant from the room.Â  Appellant, however, did not stop there.Â  Appellant began yelling and cursing, swung a punch at his teacher as he left the classroom, and continued his tirade as he was escorted down the hall.Â  
Moreover, Appellant had prior notice that this type of conduct was prohibited.Â  A juvenile petition from May 2004 charged Appellant for a violation of the very same statute he now alleges is unconstitutionally vague pursuant to an October 2004 juvenile petition.Â  Accordingly, Appellant does not have standing to facially challenge Â§ 16-17-420 on grounds of vagueness.
Because Appellant does not have standing to challenge Â§ 16-17-420 on grounds of vagueness, we do not address the merits of his argument that the terms of Â§ 16-17-420 are so vague that a person of common intelligence must necessarily guess at its meaning.Â  See Broadrick, 413 U.S. at 607 (quoting Connally v. General Construction Co., 269 U.S. 385, 391 (1926)).Â  The family courtâ€™s ruling that Â§ 16-17-420 is not unconstitutionally vague is vacated.
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the family courtâ€™s decision that Â§ 16-17-420 is not unconstitutionally overbroad.Â  Because Appellant does not have standing to challenge Â§ 16-17-420 for vagueness, the family courtâ€™s decision on that matter is vacated.Â  
MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] An appeal involving â€œa challenge on state or federal grounds to the constitutionality of a state law . . . Â where the principal issue is one of the constitutionality of the lawâ€ is heard in this Court.Â  Rule 203(d)(1)(A)(ii), SCACR.
[2] The traditional rule of standing for facial attacks provides that one to whom application of a statute is constitutional may not attack the statute on grounds that it might be unconstitutional when applied to other people or situations.Â  United States v. Raines, 362 U.S. 17, 52 (1971).
[3] A facial challenge in this context is a claim that the law is incapable of any valid application.Â  Village of Hoffman Estates v. Flipside, Hoffman Estates, Inc. 455 U.S. 489, 494 n. 5 (1982).Â  
[4] Breach of the peace statutes are generally attacked on grounds of overbreadth and vagueness because if not drafted with proper specificity, they have a strong potential for infringement on First Amendment rights in otherwise peaceable assembly.Â  See Coates v. Cincinnati, 402 U.S. 611 (1971); Cox, 379 U.S. 559; Edwards, 372 U.S. 229. However, Grayned and its progeny clearly indicate that the constitutionality of statutes that specifically address a â€œbreach of the peaceâ€ in schools are to be considered in light of the â€œspecial characteristics of the school environment.â€Â  408 U.S. at 116 (quoting Tinker, 393 U.S. at 506).
[5] The General Assembly originally enacted Â§ 16-17-420(1) in 1919 as a statute to protect schools for â€œwomen and girls.â€ 1919 S.C. Acts 239.Â  The statute was amended in 1968 to apply to â€œanyâ€ school.Â  1968 S.C. Acts 2308.Â  Today Â§ 16-17-420 is part of Title 16, Chapter 17 of the South Carolina Code which is appropriately titled â€œOffenses Against Public Policy.â€Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Kamell Delshawn Evans, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenville County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26220
Heard October 3, 2006 - Filed November 6, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka,Â  and Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia, and Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  This is a death penalty case.Â  Kamell Delshawn Evans (Appellant) was convicted of two counts of murder, two counts of possession of weapon during the commission or the attempt to commit a violent crime, two counts of kidnapping, and first-degree burglary. Â During sentencing, the jury was charged on four aggravating circumstances[1] and three mitigating circumstances.[2]Â  The jury found aggravating circumstances present, and the court imposed a death sentence for both counts of murder.Â  The court also sentenced Appellant to life in prison for the first-degree burglary.[3]Â  This opinion consolidates Appellant's direct appeal and the sentence review required by S.C. Code. Ann. Â§ 16-3-25 (2003). Â We affirm.
FACTS
The material facts are undisputed.Â  The victims were the father and brother of the Appellantâ€™s ex-girlfriend.Â  On the night of April 1, 2003, Appellant entered the home of the two victims and held them hostage for 4 Â½ hours.Â  Despite negotiations with local police and pleas for the release of the victims by Appellantâ€™s friends and family, Appellant shot the two victims in the head, killing them.
Appellant admitted shooting both victims and was convicted on all charges.Â  Appellant did not request any statutory mitigators in addition to the three statutory mitigating circumstances submitted to the jury, and he did not object to any of the jury charges during the sentencing phase.
Appellant now seeks a new sentencing proceeding due to the trial judgeâ€™s failure to submit to the jury the statutory mitigating factor provided by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(C)(b)(6): the capacity of the defendant to appreciate the criminality of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirements of law was substantially impaired.Â Â  
ISSUE

  Is Appellant entitled to a new sentencing proceeding because the trial judge failed to sua sponte charge the jury on a statutory mitigating circumstance?

ANALYSIS
Appellant argues the trial judge should have submitted to the jury the mitigator relating to capacity, without regard to whether Appellant made a specific request for that mitigating circumstance at trial.Â  We disagree.
The proper procedure for the submission of statutory mitigating circumstances to the jury in the penalty phase of a capital case is found in State v. Victor, 300 S.C. 220, 224, 387 S.E.2d 248, 250 (1989):

  Once a trial judge has made an initial determination of which statutory mitigating circumstances are supported by the evidence, the defendant shall be given an opportunity on the record: (1) to waive the submission of those he does not wish considered by the jury; and (2) to request any additional mitigating statutory circumstances supported by the evidence that he wishes submitted to the jury.

Our recent cases have stated that absent a request by counsel to charge a mitigating circumstance at trial, the issue whether the mitigator should have been charged is not preserved for review.Â  See State v. Humphries, 325 S.C. 28, 36, 479 S.E.2d 52, 57 (1996); State v. Vazquez, 364 S.C. 293, 301, 613 S.E.2d 359, 363 (2005); State v. Bowman, 366 S.C. 485, 494, 623 S.E.2d 378, 383 (2005); and State v. Sapp, 366 S.C. 283, 621 S.E.2d 883, n.3 (2005).
Appellant cites State v. Caldwell, 300 S.C. 494, 388 S.E.2d 816 (1990), to support his position.Â  In Caldwell, we held the trial judge erred by failing to charge the mitigating circumstances found in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(C)(b)(2), (6), and (7) after evidence was presented of the defendantâ€™s mental disorder, even though these mitigating charges were never requested.Â  
Caldwell, however, does not support Appellantâ€™s position because we reviewed that error in favorem vitae.[4]Â  Caldwell, 300 S.C. at 506, 388 S.E.2d at 823.Â  We abolished the doctrine of in favorem vitae in State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991) (Toal, J., concurring).Â  In Torrence we stated, â€œa contemporaneous objection is necessary in all trials beginning after the date of this opinion to properly preserve errors for our direct appellate review.â€ Torrence, 305 S.C. at 69, 406 S.E.2d at 328.
Two post-Torrence cases have held that when the defendant is intoxicated at the time of the capital crime, the trial judge must submit three statutory mitigating circumstances[5] to the jury.Â  See State v. Young, 305 S.C. 380, 409 S.E.2d 352 (1991); State v. Stone, 350 S.C. 442, 567 S.E.2d 244 (2002).Â  Recent cases have cited Stone as holding that a trial judge is required to charge those intoxication mitigators regardless whether they are requested at trial.Â  See, e.g., Bowman, 366 S.C. at 494, 623 S.E.2d at 383 (acknowledging holding of State v. Stone, supra, as requiring trial court to submit mitigating circumstances to jury if there is evidence of intoxication, regardless of whether they are requested); Â Vazquez, 364 S.C. at 301, 613 S.E.2d at 363 (same).Â  
We never explicitly stated in Young, Stone, or any other intoxication case that statutory mitigating circumstances related to intoxication must be submitted to the jury even if the defendant does not request them.[6]Â  Our intoxication cases have not created an exception to the post-Torrence preservation requirements for challenging jury charges during a capital sentencing proceeding.Â  
Although there is some evidence of drinking in the days leading up to the incident, intoxication at the time of murders is not at issue here.Â  Appellant argues that this purported preservation exception in intoxication cases also applies to mitigators stemming from mental disorders.Â  For the reasons previously stated, no such exception exists.
By failing to make a contemporaneous objection or request for the capacity mitigator, Appellant did not properly preserve this issue for our review.Â  Accordingly, we decline to address whether the evidence supported the submission of the mitigating circumstance of Appellantâ€™s capacity.
PROPORTIONALITY REVIEW
This Court must conduct a proportionality review of Appellantâ€™s death sentence based on the record.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(A) (2003).Â  In conducting the review, we consider similar cases in which the death penalty has been upheld.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(E).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Appellantâ€™s death sentence was not the result of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor, and the evidence supports the juryâ€™s findings of aggravation.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C).Â  Further, in relation to sentences in similar cases, Appellantâ€™s sentence was neither excessive nor disproportionate to his crime.Â  See Vazquez, supra (involving a double murder committed in the course of robbery); State v. Woomer, 278 S.C. 468, 299 S.E.2d 317 (1982) (involving murder after a hostage situation); State v. Shuler, 353 S.C. 176, 577 S.E.2d 438 (2003) (involving a triple murder committed in the course of burglary); and State v. Hughey, 339 S.C. 439, 529 S.E.2d 721 (2000) (involving a double murder committed in the course of burglary).
CONCLUSION
Appellantâ€™s claim that the trial judge should have charged the jury on the statutory mitigating circumstance relating to capacity is not preserved for our review.Â  Finally, the punishment was appropriate to the crime.Â  Appellantâ€™s sentence is 
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.

[1] The aggravating circumstances were: (1) the murder was committed while in the commission of the crime or act of kidnapping; (2) the murder was committed while in the commission of the crime or act of burglary in the first degree; (3) two or more persons were murdered by the defendant pursuant to one act or one scheme or course of conduct; and (4) the murder was of a law enforcement officer during or because of the performance of his official duties. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(C)(a)(1)(b) and (c), -20(C)(a)(7), and -20(C)(a)(9) (2003).Â  The fourth aggravator applied to only one of the victims, a sheriffâ€™s deputy returning home after his shift ended.
[2] The mitigating circumstances were: (1) the defendant has no significant history of prior criminal conviction involving the use of violence against another person; (2) the murder was committed while the defendant was under the influence of mental or emotional disturbance; and (3) the age or mentality of the defendant at the time of the crime.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(C)(b)(1), (2), and (7) (2003).
[3] No sentences were imposed for the kidnapping and weapon convictions pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-910 (2003) and Â§ 16-23-490(A) (2003).
[4] Meaning literally â€œin favor of life,â€ the doctrine of in favorem vitae allowed us to review the entire record on appeal for legal error and to address those errors even when no objection was made at trial.
[5] S.C Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(C)(b)(2): the murder was committed while the defendant was under the influence of mental or emotional disturbance; (6): the capacity of the defendant to appreciate the criminality of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirements of law was substantially impaired; and (7)Â  the age or mentality of the defendant at the time of the crime.
[6] In fact, the trial judge in Stone refused to charge the three statutory mitigating factors associated with intoxication and erroneously informed the jury that intoxication was not a mitigating factor.Â  Stone, 350 S.C. at 449-450, 567 S.E.2d at 248.Â Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

In the Matter of Former Florence County Magistrate Rena V.C. White, Respondent.

Opinion No. 26221
Submitted October 17, 2006 - Filed November 13, 2006Â Â

        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        David Michael Ballenger, of Florence, for respondent.Â Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  In this judicial disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a public reprimand pursuant to Rule 7(b), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.[1]Â  The facts as set forth in the Agreement are as follows.Â  
FACTS
While serving as a magistrate for Florence County, respondent obtained cocaine on several occasions from an individual to whom she is distantly related by marriage.Â  Respondent represents she usually paid only $20 for the cocaine (indicating, according to respondent, that the amount purchased on each occasion was small).Â  The cocaine was purchased for respondentâ€™s own use; she did not share the cocaine with anyone else. 
Criminal charges against the individual from whom respondent purchased the cocaine were pending during some portion of the period during which respondent purchased the cocaine.Â  The criminal charges were either pending against the individual in Florence County Magistrateâ€™s Court or pending in other courts and related proceedings were conducted in Florence County Magistrateâ€™s Court.Â  
In mitigation, respondent represents she consumed the cocaine in an effort to cope with a severe illness of a close family member.Â  ODC has no factual basis to contest this representation.Â  
Respondent acknowledges that, on multiple occasions, she used her judicial position to obtain favorable treatment for
other individuals.Â  At least one of these individuals was related to respondent.Â  Â 
Respondent was arrested on a charge of misconduct/malfeasance in office.Â  The charge is pending before the Court of General Sessions for Florence County. Â After her arrest, respondent tendered her resignation as magistrate to the Governor.Â  The Governor accepted respondentâ€™s resignation. 
LAW
By her misconduct, respondent admits she has violated the following Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR:Â  Canon 1 (judge shall uphold the integrity of the judiciary); Canon 1A (judge should participate in establishing, maintaining, and enforcing high standards of conduct and shall personally observe those standards so that the integrity and independence of the judiciary will be preserved); Canon 3 (judge shall perform duties of judicial office impartially); Canon 3A (judicial duties take precedence over all of judgeâ€™s other activities); Canon 3B(2) (judge shall be faithful to the law); Canon 3B(5) (judge shall perform judicial duties without bias); Canon 4 (judge shall conduct extra-judicial activities so as to minimize risk of conflict with judicial obligations); Canon 4A(1) (judge shall conduct all extra-judicial activities so that they do not cast reasonable doubt on the judgeâ€™s capacity to act impartially as a judge); Canon 4A(2) (judge shall conduct all extra-judicial activities so they do not demean the judicial office); Canon 4A(3) (judge shall conduct all extra-judicial activities so that they do not interfere with proper performance of judicial duties); and Canon 4D(1)(a) (judge shall not engage in financial dealings that may reasonably be perceived to exploit the judgeâ€™s judicial position).Â  Respondent also admits she has violated Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate the Code of Judicial Conduct) and Rule 7(a)(9) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate the Oath of Office) of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  
CONCLUSION 
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and issue a public reprimand.Â  Respondent shall not apply for, seek, or accept any judicial position whatsoever in this State without the prior written authorization of this Court after due service on ODC of any petition seeking the Courtâ€™s authorization.Â  Respondent is hereby reprimanded for her misconduct.Â  
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Respondent no longer holds judicial office.Â  A public reprimand is the most severe sanction the Court can impose when a judge no longer holds judicial office.Â  See In re Oâ€™Kelley, 361 S.C. 30, 603 S.E.2d 410 (2004); In re Gravely, 321 S.C. 235, 467 S.E.2d 924 (1996).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Craig A. Hurst, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        East Coast Hockey League, Inc.; Knoxville Cherokees Hockey, Inc., d/b/a Pee Dee Pride Hockey, and d/b/a Florence Pride Hockey; Florence City-County Civic Center Commission d/b/a Florence City-County Civic Center; City of Florence; and County of Florence, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26222Â Â  
Heard October 4, 2006 - Filed November 13, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Stephen J. Wukela, of Florence, for Appellant.
        Robert T. King, of Willcox, Buyck & Williams, of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Craig A. Hurst (Appellant) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of East Coast Hockey League, Inc.; Knoxville Cherokees Hockey, Inc., d/b/a Pee Dee Pride Jockey, and d/b/a Florence Pride Hockey (â€œPrideâ€); Florence City-County Civic Center Commission (â€œCommissionâ€) d/b/a Florence City-County Civic Center (â€œCivic Centerâ€); City of Florence; and County of Florence (collectively referred to as Respondents).Â  We certified the case for review from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  We affirm. 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Appellant filed this negligence action against Respondents for injuries he sustained while attending a Pride hockey game at the Civic Center on January 11, 2002.Â  During pregame warm-ups, Appellant entered the spectator area at the Civic Center through a curtained concourse entrance behind one of the goals.Â  Appellant was struck in the face by a puck while standing behind the goal.Â  
 At the time of the accident, the ice rink at the Civic Center was encircled by dasher boards and a protective Plexiglas wall, which was attached to the top of the dasher boards.Â  Also at that time, the Pride was a member of the East Coast Hockey League, Inc., a professional hockey league.Â  The Pride played home games at the Civic Center under a lease with the Commission.Â  The Civic Center was maintained and operated by the Commission, a governmental entity created by the City of Florence and the County of Florence.Â  
 After a hearing on the matter, the circuit court determined the risk of pucks leaving the ice rink and entering the spectator area is well-known, obvious, and inherent to the game of hockey.Â  The circuit court granted summary judgment in favor of Respondents based on the doctrine of primary implied assumption of risk.Â  
ISSUE

  Did the circuit court err in granting summary judgment?Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellant argues the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment for Respondents based on the doctrine of primary implied assumption of risk.Â  We disagree.
To prove negligence, a plaintiff must prove the following elements: (1) a duty owed to the plaintiff by the defendant, (2) a breach of that duty by the defendant, and (3) damages proximately resulting from the breach of duty.Â  Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing and Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 387, 520 S.E.2d 142, 149 (1999). Â The court must determine, as a matter of law, whether the law recognizes a particular duty.Â  If there is no duty, then the defendant in a negligence action is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law. Id. at 387, 520 S.E.2d at 149.
â€œPrimary implied assumption of risk arises when the plaintiff impliedly assumes those risks that are inherent in a particular activity.â€Â  Davenport v. Cotton Hope Plantation Horizontal Prop. Regime, 333 S.C. 71, 81, 508 S.E.2d 565, 570 (1998) (emphasis in original).[1]Â  The Davenport Court further explained the doctrine as follows:

  Primary implied assumption of risk is not a true affirmative defense, Â  but instead goes to the initial determination of whether the defendantâ€™s legal duty encompasses the risk encountered by the plaintiff. . . .[T]he Tennessee Supreme Court summarized the doctrine in the following way:Â  
  
    In its primary sense, implied assumption of risk focuses not on the plaintiffâ€™s conduct in assuming the risk, but on the defendantâ€™s general duty of care. . . .Clearly primary implied assumption of risk is but another way of stating the conclusion that a plaintiff has failed to establish a prima facie case [of negligence] by failing to establish that a duty exists.
  
  [Perez v. McConkey, 872 S.W.2d 897, 902 (Tenn. 1994)].Â  In this sense, primary implied assumption of risk is simply a part of the initial negligence analysis.Â  

333 S.C. at 81, 508 S.E.2d at 570 (internal citations omitted); see also id. at 81 n.3, 508 S.E.2d at 570 n.3 (finding Gunther v. Charlotte Baseball, Inc., 854 F.Supp. 424 (D.S.C. 1994) implicitly applied primary implied assumption of risk).Â  
The issue before the Court is whether Respondents owed a duty of care to protect Appellant from flying pucks.Â  We find Gunther instructive because the risk of being injured by a foul ball at a baseball game and the risk of being injured by a flying puck at a hockey game are similar risks.Â  See also Modec v. City of Eveleth, 29 N.W.2d 453, 456 (Minn. 1947) (finding no difference between baseball and hockey when determining liability for injuries sustained from a foul ball or a flying puck); Pestalozzi v. Philadelphia Flyers Ltd., 576 A.2d 72, 74 (Pa. Super. Ct. 1990) (finding no difference between flying balls and flying pucks when determining the risk assumed by the spectators of baseball and hockey games).Â  In Gunther, a spectator who was struck in the face by a foul ball during a baseball game sued the owner of the baseball team and the stadium alleging negligence.Â  854 F.Supp. at 425.Â  The Gunther Court found â€œthe vast majority of jurisdictions recognize this hazard [of being struck by a foul ball] to be a risk that is assumed by the spectators because it remains after due care has been exercised (erecting a screen), and it is not the result of negligence by the ball club.Â  Id. at 428 (citing Anderson v. Kansas City Baseball Club, 231 S.W.2d 170 (Mo. 1950)).Â  The Gunther Court then found the spectator voluntarily assumed the risk of her injuries and granted summary judgment to the owner and the stadium. 
Under the doctrine of implied primary assumption of risk, Respondentsâ€™ duty of care did not encompass the risk involved.Â  The risk of a hockey spectator being struck by a flying puck is inherent to the game of hockey and is also a common, expected, and frequent risk of hockey.Â  See generally Prosser & Keeton, The Law of Torts Â§ 684 (5th ed. 1984) (â€œ[T]hose who participate or sit as spectators at sports . . . may be taken to assume the known risks of being hurt by . . . hockey pucks. . . .â€).Â  Respondents did not have a duty to protect Appellant, a spectator, from inherent risks of the game of hockey.[2]Â  See also Nemarnik v. Los Angeles Kings Hockey Club, L.P., 127 Cal. Rptr. 2d 10 (Ct. App. 2002) (hockey arena owners and operators, hockey league, and professional ice hockey team did not owe a duty to spectator to eliminate the inherent risk of injury from flying pucks); Modec, 29 N.W.2d at 456-57 (spectator at hockey game assumes risk of injury from inherent risks of game); Ingersoll v. Onondaga Hockey Club Inc., 281 N.Y.S. 505 (Sup. Ct. 1935) (hockey rink operators did not owe a duty to protect a spectator from flying pucks, which is a risk incidental to the activity); Pestalozzi, 576 A.2d at 74-75 (same); Kennedy v. Providence Hockey Club, Inc., 376 A.2d 329 (R.I. 1977) (spectator at a hockey game assumed risk of injury from flying pucks); see generally W.E. Shipley, Liability for Injury to One Attending Hockey Game or Exhibition, 14 A.L.R.3d 1018 (1967) (collecting cases that involve the issue of whether a hockey arena owner or operator owes a duty to protect hockey spectators from flying pucks). 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing analysis, we conclude Appellantâ€™s action fails as a matter of law under primary implied assumption of risk.Â  The circuit court properly granted summary judgment for Respondents.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  The Davenport Court also found the adoption of comparative negligence in this state did not affect the doctrine of primary implied assumption of risk.Â  333 S.C. at 87, 508 S.E.2d at 574. 
[2]Â  Â The application of the primary implied assumption of risk doctrine to a hockey spectator may not completely absolve hockey arena owners and operators of all duties.Â  See, e.g., Wagner v. Thomas J. Obert Enters., 396 N.W.2d 223 (Minn. 1986) (primary implied assumption of risk did not apply to negligent maintenance and supervision of a skating rink because these are not inherent risks of skating).

BENCH MEMORANDUM

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Madison, a fictitious name of a mentally disabled person, through her court-appointed guardian, Brenda Bryant, Appellant,
v.
Babcock Center, Inc., a South Carolina Corporation; South Carolina Department of Disabilities and Special Needs; and Michelle Batchelor, in her official and individual capacities, Respondents.
      
    
  


ORDER

Respondent (South Carolina Department of Disabilities and Special Needs) filed a petition for rehearing in which they asked the Court to reconsider its opinion holding that a private treatment center owes a duty of care to a mentally retarded person admitted to its facility and holding that a state agency which has a contract with the center owes a duty of care to the person.
We deny the petition for rehearing, withdraw the former opinion, and substitute the attached opinion.

   
     
     
      s/Jean H. Toal                                    
        Â  C.J.
        
        s/James E. Moore

concurrence 
        
        s/Costa M. Pleicones
