text:
IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Rosalyn Kimberly Grigsby, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26226
Submitted October 2, 2006 - Filed November 20, 2006Â Â 

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and C. Tex Davis, Jr., Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
Paulette Edwards, of Law Office of Paulette Edwards, PA, of Columbia, for respondent.Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a definite suspension not to exceed two (2) years.Â  See Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  She requests the suspension be made retroactive to the date of her interim suspension. [1]Â  We accept the Agreement and impose a definite suspension of two years, retroactive to the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.Â  
FACTS
Matter I
Complainant A consulted with respondent about handling a domestic matter.Â  Complainant A provided several documents to respondent and paid a retainer.Â  After approximately three months, respondent had not made any progress on the case.Â  Respondent eventually referred Complainant A to another attorney and refunded a portion of the retainer.Â  
During the course of the investigation, ODC assigned this matter to an Attorney to Assist (ATA).Â  Respondent failed to timely respond to the ATAâ€™s request to schedule a meeting to address the allegations.Â  In addition, respondent failed to follow through on her promise to the ATA to provide certain documents which could corroborate her version of the events relevant to the investigation.
Matter II
Complainant B retained respondent to handle a child custody action.Â  Respondent failed to effectively explain the scopeÂ of her representation to Complainant B, which prevented Complainant B from making an informed decision about her case.Â  In addition, respondent made several comments about Complainant B whichÂ  Complainant B found to be demeaning and unprofessional.Â Â  
Matter III
Complainant C retained respondent to handle a child support matter.Â  Respondent failed to respond to several of Complainant Câ€™s telephone messages in a timely manner.Â  Complainant C became frustrated with respondentâ€™s failure to prepare and file pleadings to address her concerns.Â  Respondent admits that some of Complainant Câ€™s concerns could have been alleviated had respondent more effectively explained the litigation process and procedures.Â  
Matter IV
In October 2003, Complainant D retained respondent to handle a modification of child support and visitation.Â  Subsequent to the initial consultation and two brief telephone conversations, Complainant D was unable to communicate with respondent.Â  Complainant D left numerous telephone messages for respondent seeking an update on the status of her case and received no response.Â  In addition, Complainant D mailed two certified letters to respondent, both of which were returned without response.Â  
When Complainant D telephoned respondentâ€™s office in December 2003, she learned the office telephone number had been disconnected.Â  Respondent had not provided any updated contact information.Â  Complainant D subsequently discovered respondent had failed to file the pleadings and that little to no progress had been made with her case.Â Â Â  
Matter V
Complainant C filed an application for relief with the Resolution of Fee Disputes Board (the Board).Â  The Board assigned Maren Sherman, Esquire, to investigate the claim.Â  Ms. Sherman attempted to communicate with respondent on numerous occasions, leaving several telephone messages for respondent.Â  Respondent failed to respond to any of the messages.Â  Thereafter, on March 29, 2004, the Board issued its ruling, ordering respondent to return $650.00 to Complainant C.Â  Respondent failed to comply with the ruling or to respond in any manner.Â  The Board issued a Certificate of Noncompliance on May 20, 2004, for respondentâ€™s continued failure to comply with its ruling.Â  
Complainant D also filed an application for relief with theÂ  Board.Â  The Board issued its ruling that respondent should return $1,000.00 to Complainant D.Â  The Board sent notice of its ruling to respondentâ€™s official address.Â  Respondent failed to comply with the ruling or respond in any manner.Â  On September 10, 2004, the Board issued a Certificate of Noncompliance due to respondentâ€™s continued failure to comply with the ruling of the Board.Â  After respondent relocated out-of-state, she failed to officially notify and provide the South Carolina Bar with her new contact information.Â  
Matter VI
Complainant E retained respondent to handle a workerâ€™s compensation case.Â  Complainant Eâ€™s claim was denied after a hearing in May 2003, however, Complainant E still had legal remedies available.Â  On numerous occasions, Complainant E attempted to communicate with respondent about the options for her case.Â  Respondent failed to respond to Complainant Eâ€™s messages.Â  Complainant E discovered respondentâ€™s office telephone number had been disconnected and that her office had been vacated.Â  Respondent withdrew from representation without ensuring that Complainant E was aware of the circumstances and that adequate provisions had been made to protect Complainant Eâ€™s interests.
Matter VII
Complainant F retained respondent to handle a child custody/visitation matter.Â Â  Shortly after being retained, respondent verbally informed Complainant F that she would be moving out of state, but she assured Complainant F that she would remain on the case until completion.Â  Respondent appeared with Complainant F at one hearing, although communication after the hearing quickly deteriorated.
Respondent relocated out of state.Â  Respondent failed to provide Complainant F with her current address and telephone number. 
Complainant F believed respondent was continuing to work on the case but, without Complainant Fâ€™s knowledge or consent, respondent had forwarded Complainant Fâ€™s case file to another attorney.Â  Respondent failed to take the necessary actions to withdraw from the representation in order to protect Complainant Fâ€™s interests.Â Â  
Complainant F learned of the date and time for an upcoming hearing from opposing counsel.Â  Respondent later telephoned Complainant F and apologized for failing to inform her of the hearing date.Â  
On or about June 28, 2004, respondent spoke with Complainant F and, once again, gave her false assurances that she would be able to handle the case through to its completion.Â  At the time of this conversation, respondent knew that an order placing her on interim suspension had been or would be issued shortly.Â  Respondent failed to promptly notify Complainant F, as well as several other clients, as required by Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, that she had been suspended from the practice of law.Â  In addition, she failed to formally withdraw from representation of Complainant F after the suspension as provided by Rule 30, RLDE.Â  Â Â 
LAW
Respondent admits that her misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under Rule 413, RLDE, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers); Rule 7(a)(5) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law); and Rule 7(a)(10) (lawyer shall not willfully fail to comply with a final decision of the Resolution of Fee Disputes Board).Â  In addition, respondent admits she has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to client ); Rule 1.2 (lawyer shall consult with client about objectives of representation); Rule 1.3Â  (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep client reasonably informed about status of a matter, promptly comply with reasonable requests for information, and explain matter to extent reasonably necessary to permit client to make informed decisions regarding the representation); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall safe keep client property); Rule 1.16 (upon termination of representation, lawyer shall take steps to the extent reasonably practicable to protect clientâ€™s interests, including reasonable notice to client and refunding of unearned advance payment fee); Rule 3.2 (lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to expedite litigation consistent with interests of client); Rule 8.1 (lawyer shall not knowingly fail to respond to lawful demand for information from disciplinary authority); and
Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and impose a definite suspension of two years, retroactive to the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that she has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413,
SCACR.
 DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Respondent was placed on interim suspension on June 29, 2004.Â  In the Matter of Grigsby, 360 S.C. 48, 599 S.E.2d 455 (2004).Â

title: Ellison v. Frigidaire Home Products
description: In this workers' compensation case, the Court construes section 42-9-400 to allow recovery for the combined effects of a workplace injury and pre-existing conditions.
text:
ellison v. frigidaire


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Ronnie Ellison, Petitioner,
v.
Frigidaire Home Products, Employer, and WCI Outdoor Products, Carrier,
Respondents.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO 
THE COURT OF APPEALS 

Appeal from Orangeburg County
Diane S. Goodstein, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26227
Heard October 3, 2006 - Filed November 20, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
Edgar W. Dickson, of Williams & Williams, of Orangeburg, for petitioner.
E. Ros Huff, Jr., of Huff Law Firm, LLC, of Irmo, for respondents.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  This is a workersâ€™ compensation case.Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision reversing the commissionâ€™s award of total disability.[1]Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Petitioner Ellison was working full-time when he fractured his left leg in an on-the-job forklift accident.Â  He was given a 20% permanent impairment rating to the leg.Â  Petitioner also had pre-existing physical conditions including hypertension, sleep apnea, prostate cancer, diabetes, and congestive cardiac disease which, in combination with his workplace injury, rendered him physically unable to return to work after his accident.Â  The single commissioner found petitioner permanently and totally disabled.Â  The commissionerâ€™s order was affirmed by the full commission and the circuit court.Â  
Respondent Frigidaire Home Products (Employer) appealed to the Court of Appeals which reversed the commissionâ€™s order. The Court of Appeals held petitionerâ€™s recovery was limited to the 20% impairment to his leg.Â  
ISSUE

Did the Court of Appeals err in holding that petitionerâ€™s pre-existing conditions should not be considered in determining his compensable disability?

DISCUSSION
The single commissioner, affirmed by the full commission and the circuit court, found petitioner totally disabled under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-400 (1985 & Supp. 2005) which provides in pertinent part:

(a) If an employee who has a permanent physical impairment from any cause or origin incurs a subsequent disability from injury by accident arising out of and in the course of his employment, resulting in compensation and medical payments liability or either, for disability that is substantially greater, by reason of the combined effects of the preexisting impairment and subsequent injury or by reason of the aggravation of the preexisting impairment, than that which would have resulted from the subsequent injury alone, the employer or his insurance carrier shall in the first instance pay all awards of compensation and medical benefits provided by this Title;Â  but such employer or his insurance carrier shall be reimbursed from the Second Injury Fund . . . .

. . . .

(d) As used in this section, â€œpermanent physical impairmentâ€ means any permanent condition, whether congenital or due to injury or disease, of such seriousness as to constitute a hindrance or obstacle to obtaining employment or to obtaining reemployment if the employee should become unemployed.

(emphasis added).Â  
Applying this section, the commissioner concluded petitioner was totally disabled from the combined effect of his pre-existing conditions and the workplace injury to his leg.Â  The record supports the commissionerâ€™s finding that petitioner is no longer able to work.Â  Significantly, there is no finding that petitionerâ€™s pre-existing conditions aggravated his leg injury or that the leg injury aggravated his pre-existing conditions.Â  
In reversing petitionerâ€™s award, the Court of Appeals found Â§ 42-9-400 inapplicable and instead relied on Singleton v. Young Lumber Co., 236 S.C. 454, 114 S.E.2d 837 (1960), to rule that petitionerâ€™s compensation was limited to the amount specified for the leg as a scheduled member under the scheduled injury statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-30 (1985 & Supp. 2005).Â  The Court of Appeals held petitioner could not recover total disability compensation, no matter how debilitating his pre-existing conditions were, because there was no causal connection with his workplace injury.
We conclude the Court of Appeals erred in relying on Singleton.Â  Singleton involved a sole injury to a scheduled member - no other condition was claimed to have contributed to disability.Â  The argument was that the injury to the scheduled member, a leg, was itself so disabling that the claimant should be found totally disabled.Â  This Court held that because the injury was confined to a scheduled member, compensation must be determined under the scheduled injury statute as provided by the legislature.Â  236 S.C. at 473, 114 S.E.2d at 846.Â  Singleton stands simply for the proposition that impairment involving only a scheduled member is compensated under the scheduled injury statute and not the general disability statute.[2]Â  The issue whether greater disability may be awarded where there is an additional impairment without a causal link has never come squarely before us although we have specifically allowed greater disability when there is a causal link.[3]Â Â Â  
Workersâ€™ compensation statutes are to be construed liberally in favor of coverage.Â  Mauldin v. Dyna-Color/Jack Rabbit, 308 S.C. 18, 416 S.E.2d 639 (1992).Â  We hold the commissioner correctly found
Â§ 42-9-400 controlling here.Â  This statute was enacted in 1972, several years after our decision in Singleton.Â  The language of Â§ 42-9-400(a) and (d) indicates the legislature clearly envisioned that a claimant may recover for greater disability than that incurred from a single injury to a particular body part if the combination with any pre-existing condition hinders reemployment.Â  There is no requirement that the pre-existing condition aggravated the injury, or that the injury aggravated the pre-existing condition, so long as there is a greater disability simply from the â€œcombined effectsâ€ of the injury and the pre-existing condition.[4] Â  
The Court of Appeals reasoned that Â§ 42-9-400 was not applicable because it merely entitles an employerâ€™s insurance carrier to be reimbursed by the Second Injury Fund.Â  We disagree.Â  Providing for an employerâ€™s reimbursement from the Fund for the â€œcombined effectsâ€ of a workplace injury and pre-existing conditions would be futile unless a claimant could actually make such a recovery in the first place.Â  We presume the legislature intends to accomplish something by its enactments and that it would not do a futile thing. Â Gordon v. Phillips Utilities, Inc., 362 S.C. 403, 608 S.E.2d 425 (2005).Â Â  
In conclusion, the Court of Appeals erred in relying on Singleton Â and refusing to apply Â§ 42-9-400. Â Accordingly, we reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision and reinstate the commissionâ€™s award for total disability.
 REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Ellison v. Frigidaire Home Prods., 360 S.C. 236, 600 S.E.2d 120 (Ct. App. 2004).Â Â  
[2]Singleton does state that â€œ[w]here the injury is confined to the scheduled member, and there is no impairment of any other part of the body because of such injury, the employee is limited to the scheduled compensation. . . .â€Â  236 S.C. at 471, 114 S.E.2d at 845 (emphasis added).Â  This statement is simply dictum, however, because there was no issue of any additional impairment in Singleton, causally related or not.Â  This dictum has been subsequently cited but never to support a holding on the precise issue here.Â  See Therrell v. Jerryâ€™s Inc., 370 S.C. 22, ___, 633 S.E.2d 893, 895, n.2 (2006) (case holds torn rotator cuff is not limited to scheduled recovery for arm); Wigfall v. Tideland Utilities, Inc., 354 S.C. 100, 103, 580 S.E.2d 100, 101 (2003) (case holds medical and wage losses are not considered an additional impairment to injury to scheduled member); Lee v. Harborside CafÃ©, 350 S.C. 74, 78, 564 S.E.2d 354, 356 (Ct. App. 2002) (case holds psychological system is not a scheduled member); Simmons v. City of Charleston, 349 S.C. 64, 75, 562 S.E.2d 476, 482 (Ct. App. 2002) (case holds injury to scheduled member that affected other parts of body compensable as general disability); Brown v. Owen Steel Co., 316 S.C. 278, 280, 450 S.E.2d 57, 58 (Ct. App. 1994) (case holds injury to back is compensable as scheduled member).
In Wigfall, supra, we reaffirmed our holding in Singleton that an injury to a scheduled member which is the sole cause of the claimantâ€™s disability may be compensated only under the scheduled injury statute.Â  We concluded that the â€œimpairmentâ€ mentioned in Singleton means only â€œphysical deficiency.â€Â  354 S.C. at 104, 580 S.E.2d at 102.Â  Here, petitioner is claiming total disability from the combined effect of his workplace injury and his pre-existing physical deficiencies.Â  Further, Â§ 42-9-400, which is an issue here, was not an issue in Wigfall because there was no question of a combined effect with pre-existing conditions.
[3] E.g., Anderson v. Baptist Med. Center, 343 S.C. 487, 541 S.E.2d 526 (2001) (workplace injuries aggravated pre-existing psychological condition); Brown v. R.L. Jordan Oil Co., 291 S.C. 272, 353 S.E.2d 280 (1987) (workplace injury aggravated pre-existing thrombophlebitis); see also Simmons v. City of Charleston, supra.
[4]In fact, the statute provides for the aggravation of a pre-existing condition as an alternative to the combined effects provision.

title: In the Matter of Brigina Dicks-Woolridge
description: This is an attorney disciplinary matter.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Brigina Dicks-Woolridge, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26228
Heard October 17, 2006 - Filed November 20, 2006Â Â 

DISBARRED


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Senior Assistant Disciplinary Counsel; both of Columbia, for Â Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
Brigina Dicks-Woolridge, of Florence, pro se.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, the Commission on Lawyer Conduct filed formal charges against respondent.[1]Â  A hearing before the sub-panel, which respondent did not attend, was held regarding the charges.Â  The sub-panel recommended respondent be disbarred from the practice of law.Â  The full panel adopted the sub-panelâ€™s report and
recommendations. 
FACTS
The essential nature of the charges against respondent involve failing to act diligently for or communicate with her clients, failing to maintain unearned fees and to keep client funds in a trust account, using funds in the trust account for her own benefit, and failing to cooperate with Disciplinary Counsel in the investigation of these matters.
The Jackson Matter
On December 14, 2001, respondent conducted the closing on the sale of a house owned by Jackson and his former wife.Â  The settlement statement respondent prepared did not accurately reflect the actual transaction.Â  Further, respondent withheld $30,913.87 from the closing to pay off the mortgage; however, she did not immediately pay it off.Â  Thereafter, respondentâ€™s trust account balance fell below the amount required to pay off the mortgage, and the amount was not restored until January 31, 2002.Â  At that time, she paid off the mortgage.Â  Respondent failed to produce sufficient records during the disciplinary investigation to determine the source of the deposit that restored the balance.
Although respondent paid Jacksonâ€™s mortgage on January 31, 2002, she did not file the deed and completed mortgage until January 2003, almost a year after the closing.Â  The payment of the mortgage and recording fees left a ledger balance of $892.00, which reflects the amount still owed to Jackson and his former wife.Â  Review of the bank statements indicated the balance in the trust account dropped below the ledger balance twice.
The panel found there is clear and convincing evidence respondent failed to act with diligence in this matter in violation of Rule 1.3 of Rule 407, SCACR, failed to keep safe her clientsâ€™ funds in violation of Rule 1.15 of Rule 407, SCACR, failed to maintain accurate or sufficient financial records in violation of Rule 417, SCACR, and that respondent engaged in a criminal act in willfully spending the funds inadvertently wired into her trust account in violation of Rule 8.4(b) and (d), of Rule 407,
SCACR.
The panel further found respondent failed to cooperate in the investigation of this matter. Â Respondent twice failed to appear to give a statement pursuant to Rule 19(c)(4) of Rule 413, RLDE.Â  Following her interim suspension, respondent ultimately appeared for a Rule 19(c)(4) statement and produced some records at that time.Â  However, she did not fully comply with the subpoena and did not appear for the conclusion of her statement even though she requested the opportunity to return and provide additional information.Â  Accordingly, the panel found respondent failed to cooperate in this matter in violation of Rule 8.1.
The Grant Matter
Respondent represented Grant regarding her claims arising from a June 2000 auto accident.Â  During the representation, Grant moved away and her mother became respondentâ€™s contact.Â  Respondent obtained a $7,000 settlement in January 2002.Â  The mother testified she received a check for her daughterâ€™s portion of the settlement but did not receive an accounting of the remaining funds.Â  The fee agreement obligated respondent to pay medical providers from the settlement proceeds.Â  However, these medical bills were not promptly paid at the time of the settlement.Â  The mother testified that both she and her daughter made a number of unsuccessful attempts to communicate with respondent about the unpaid bills.Â  According to the file produced by respondent, the bills were not all paid until May 2002, after she received notice of the grievance.
Respondent testified in her Rule 19(c)(4) appearance that the check she issued to Grant was inadvertently written from her operating account.Â  Instead of moving the amount of Grantâ€™s share from the trust account to the operating account to correct the error, respondent chose to leave those funds in the trust account and give herself a â€œcreditâ€ that she subsequently used to pay bankruptcy filing fees for various clients.Â  She kept no ledger or other accounting of those payments.
The review of respondentâ€™s trust account records revealed that she issued two trust account checks payable to herself for fees in Grantâ€™s case prior to receipt and deposit of the settlement check.Â  The trust account records show no other deposit of funds that would entitle respondent to these two payments.Â  According to the fee agreement, respondent was only entitled to one-third of the recovery.Â  Respondent did not provide an explanation for the dates or amounts of the checks to herself.
The panel found there is clear and convincing evidence respondent failed to diligently disburse the settlement proceeds in violation of Rules 1.3 and 4.4, of Rule 407, SCACR; failed to adequately communicate with Grant and her mother in violation of Rule 1.4; misappropriated $4,622.21 from her trust account when she negotiated checks payable to herself prior to deposit of funds in the account, in violation of Rules 1.15, 8.4(b), and 8.4(e); and failed to maintain the financial records related to this transaction as required by Rule 417, SCACR.[2]
The panel further found respondent failed to cooperate in the investigation of this matter.Â  She appeared pursuant to Rule 19(c)(4) and produced her client file, but was unable to produce adequate financial records to show that all of the funds received on Grantâ€™s behalf were appropriately disbursed.Â  Respondent was given fifteen days to produce those documents.Â  She failed to do so and she failed to appear at the conclusion of her Rule 19(c)(4) appearance.Â  The Panel found there is clear and convincing evidence respondent failed to cooperate in violation of Rule 8.1.
The Graham Matter
Respondent was appointed to represent Graham in a post-conviction relief matter in June 1999.Â  At the PCR hearing, the judge indicated he was going to deny the application and instructed the Attorney Generalâ€™s office to prepare an order.Â  There was a fire in respondentâ€™s office in May 2001.Â  As a result of the fire, respondentâ€™s computers were destroyed and several client files were lost or damaged. Â Grahamâ€™s original client file was lost in the fire and respondent did not take any steps to reconstruct that file.Â  She also failed to create a new file for maintenance and management of documents generated and received in Grahamâ€™s case.
Respondent admitted she did not take any action on Grahamâ€™s behalf following the PCR hearing.Â  She received a proposed order from opposing counsel in December 2001, but she did not send Graham a copy or determine the order was actually filed.Â  Respondent did not comply with Grahamâ€™s requests for copies of documents from his file, nor did she have any communication with him following the PCR hearing.Â  She did not advise him of his right to appeal.
The panel found respondentâ€™s lack of cooperation, her failure to respond to the Notice of Full Investigation, and her misrepresentations to the panel in her Answer in this matter all violated Rule 8.1, of Rule 407, SCACR.Â  The panel also found there is clear and convincing evidence that respondent violated Rules 1.1, 1.2, and 1.3 by failing to maintain a client file for Graham, failing to take any action on his behalf following his PCR hearing, and failing to advise him of his right to appeal.Â  The panel stated that the lack of attention to Grahamâ€™s legal matter amounts to conduct prejudicial to the administration of justice in violation of Rule 8.4(e).Â  The panel further found respondent failed to adequately communicate with Graham in violation of Rule 1.4 and improperly withdrew from representing him in violation of Rule 1.16.
The Allen Matter
At the hearing, Allen testified she paid respondent a $500 retainer to represent her in contempt proceedings she filed in connection with a child custody case.Â  From December 2002 to April 2003, Allen made numerous unsuccessful attempts to reach respondent by phone at her office and at home.Â  Respondent did not correspond with Allen about her case and missed an appointment with her.
In March 2003, respondent was placed on interim suspension.Â  She did not produce Allenâ€™s client file to the attorney appointed to protect her clientsâ€™ interests upon her suspension.Â  Allenâ€™s file was not located, but the attorney was able to reconstruct it from loose mail located in respondentâ€™s office and from materials received from opposing counsel.Â  From the panelâ€™s review of the file it appeared respondent did not take any action on Allenâ€™s behalf other than an initial letter to opposing counsel proposing a settlement and a letter to the judge on the same date requesting a continuance.
In her Answer, respondent asserts she found Allenâ€™s client file in her office and that the attorney to protect client interests failed to properly perform his duties as trustee.Â  However, the panel noted respondent had failed to produce the file she claims to have located to Disciplinary Counsel.Â  The panel stated, given that fact, and because respondent did not appear at the hearing to present evidence to support her assertions in that regard, the matter would be resolved in favor of the attorney to protect client interests and the panel concluded that either no file was maintained for Allen or that respondent failed to turn it over to the attorney upon her interim suspension.
The panel found there is clear and convincing evidence that respondent failed to adequately communicate with Allen about her domestic matter; failed to provide even minimally competent or diligent representation of Allen; and failed to earn the fee she was paid. Accordingly, the panel found respondent violated Rules 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, and 1.5, of Rule 407, SCACR.
The McRaye Matter
McRaye paid respondent $600 for a divorce.Â  McRaye testified respondent repeatedly put off the hearing and failed to diligently pursue his case.Â  He was unable to acquire information from respondent about the status of his case despite calls and visits to her office.Â  Ultimately, McRaye fired respondent and hired someone else.Â  McRaye had to pay his new attorney additional funds to complete tasks respondent had not done or redo tasks he was unable to confirm because respondent did not timely deliver his client file.
The panel found respondent failed to competently and diligently represent McRaye in violation of Rules 1.1, 1.2, and 1.3, of Rule 407, SCACR.Â  The panel found she failed to adequately communicate with McRaye and his subsequent attorney in violation of Rules 1.4 and 1.16.Â  Finally, the panel found she violated Rule 1.5 by failing to earn the fee she charged in the case and by not refunding that fee.
The Matson Matter
Matson retained respondent to represent her in a bankruptcy matter.Â  Matson paid $600 toward a $1,175 retainer on February 2, 1999.Â  Respondent did not deposit this fee into her trust account.Â  Although Matsonâ€™s fee payment had not been deposited in her trust account, respondent wrote a trust account check to the bankruptcy court for the $175 filing fee on February 5, 1999, and a second check for $175 for a subsequent filing on March 12, 1999.
The panel found there is clear and convincing evidence respondent failed to deposit Matsonâ€™s $600 payment into her trust account.Â  The panel noted it was unclear whether this payment was for attorneyâ€™s fees or costs.Â  In either case, respondent was required to hold the funds in trust.Â  The panel found the $350 used to pay filing fees for Matson was money held on behalf of one or more other clients.Â  Based on these findings, the panel found respondent violated Rule 1.15 in this matter.
The Trust Account Matter
The panelâ€™s review of respondentâ€™s Rule 19(c)(4) testimony revealed numerous violations of the trust accounting requirements. Â Since opening her solo practice, respondent failed to conduct monthly reconciliations of her trust account.Â  The panel found respondent did not reconcile the balance in her account, but simply compared her bank statements to her files or personal recollection of deposits.Â  Even that review by respondent was done sporadically.
Respondent stated that prior to the fire in her office in May 2001, she maintained an accounting journal and client ledgers.Â  After her financial records were lost or destroyed as a result of the fire, respondent did not attempt to reconstruct those records.Â  She acknowledged that, at the time of the fire, her trust account contained money being held for clients, yet she did not make any attempt to determine who had how much on deposit.[3]
From the date of the office fire until the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension, respondent did not maintain client ledgers or an accounting journal concerning transactions that occurred after the fire.Â  Additionally, she did not reconcile her trust account for that time period.
In her Answer, respondent states that in June 2001, she noticed excess money in her trust account.Â  She did not know where the funds came from, but stated â€œthey could not have come at a better time,â€ given the fire in her law office.Â  At that time, she began to use the money â€œas needed.â€Â  In December, respondent was notified by a lender that the source of the money was an inadvertent wire transfer into her trust account.Â  The lender demanded the return of the funds.Â  Respondent confirmed the balance in her trust account was sufficient to return the money to the lender.Â  She then returned the money without regard to whose money it actually was.Â  Respondent claimed she replaced some of the client funds used to repay the lender with the proceeds of a loan on her house; however, she did not produce any document to confirm this.
In October 2001, respondent received an insurance check in the amount of $21,672.54 for damages sustained in her office fire.Â  She deposited this check into her trust account.Â  Thereafter, respondent issued two checks to herself, two checks to a remodeling company, and several checks to various payees for furniture and office equipment.Â  The notations on these checks reference respondentâ€™s insurance proceeds.Â  On June 3, 2002, respondent wrote a third trust account check to herself with a reference to her insurance claim with no corresponding deposit.Â  Review of the bank statements revealed that, during that same period, respondent deposited no other checks from her insurance company and no other deposits that correspond to the payments respondent made to herself.Â  On June 12, 2002, respondent deposited an additional check from her insurance company in the amount of $1,636.30.Â  Respondentâ€™s total deposits of fire insurance claim proceeds into the trust account were $23,308.84 and her total disbursements referencing those proceeds were $39,202.47.
In her response to the Notice of Full Investigation in this matter, respondent stated she had considered whether depositing the insurance proceeds into her trust account was commingling.Â  She concluded it was not as she was â€œessentially handling an insurance matter forâ€ herself and she was â€œrepresentingâ€ herself.Â  The panel found this statement does not explain why she chose to deposit some of the insurance checks into her trust account and some into her operating account.Â  The panel also found that her statement does not explain why she did not keep a record of those funds or why she wrote checks from the trust account in excess of the deposits.Â  The panel stated it was unable to ask for an explanation because respondent did not appear at the hearing.
The panel found there is clear and convincing evidence respondent failed to comply with the requirements of Rule 417, SCACR, prior to the fire in her office.Â  The panel found respondent had violated Rule 1.15, of Rule 407, SCACR, and Rule 417 by failing to reconstruct even minimal documentation to determine whose funds she had in her trust account at the time of the fire.Â  The panel stated that, giving due consideration to the extreme difficulties respondent likely encountered following her office fire, they found the fact she made absolutely no attempt to maintain even minimally sufficient records of post-fire transactions for nearly two years to be misconduct rising to the level of blatant indifference to Rule 417.Â  In addition, the panel found respondent commingled her own funds with client funds when she deposited the insurance proceeds into her trust account.Â  The panel further found the issuance of checks in excess of those deposits amounted to misappropriation of $15,893.66.Â  The panel found that conduct violated Rules 8.4(b) and 8.4(d).
The panel considered mitigating and aggravating circumstances before determining the appropriate punishment to recommend for respondent.Â  As mitigating circumstances, the panel considered respondentâ€™s office fire, her reputation as an attorney, and the fact that she did not have any prior disciplinary history.
As aggravating circumstances, the panel considered (1) respondentâ€™s pattern of misconduct in failing to diligently pursue her clientsâ€™ legal matters, failing to communicate with her clients, and failing to maintain unearned fees and to safekeep client funds in the trust account; (2) her lack of full cooperation in the disciplinary investigation; (3) her experience as an Attorney to Assist charged with investigating allegations of attorney misconduct; (4) the egregiousness of respondentâ€™s conduct in using funds in her trust account for her own benefit; and (5) her failure to appear at the hearing.
The panel concluded that clear and convincing evidence warranted disbarment plus the costs of these proceedings.Â  In addition, the panel recommended the Court require respondent to make the following payments in restitution:Â  $446 to Jesse A. Jackson; $446 to Dedra Jackson; $500 to Michelle Allen; and $600 to Mingo McRaye.Â  The panel also recommended respondent be required to pay to the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection:Â  $350 for the unknown client funds used for Matsonâ€™s filing fees; $15,893.66 for the unknown client funds respondent used for fire losses and paid to herself; $2,288.88 for the funds paid to herself above the fee amount in the Grant matter; and any amount paid out by the Lawyersâ€™ Fund following respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  The panel noted respondent should receive credit for the amount that was paid to the Lawyersâ€™ Fund which represented the funds remaining in her trust account at the time of her interim suspension.
DISCUSSION
The authority to discipline attorneys and the manner in which discipline is given rests entirely with this Court.Â  In re Long, 346 S.C. 110, 551 S.E.2d 586 (2001).Â  The Court may make its own findings of fact and conclusions of law, and is not bound by the panelâ€™s recommendation.Â  In re Larkin, 336 S.C. 366, 520 S.E.2d 804 (1999).Â  The Court must administer the sanction it deems appropriate after a thorough review of the record.Â  Id.
Given the facts of this case and taking into consideration discipline rendered in similar cases, the Panelâ€™s recommendation of disbarment is appropriate.Â  See, e.g., In re Chandler, 356 S.C. 288, 588 S.E.2d 610 (2003) (disbarment where attorney failed to cooperate with disciplinary counsel and appear at his hearing; failed to communicate with and act with due diligence for his clients; caused significant financial losses to his clients and former law partner; misappropriated funds; and engaged in misconduct involving dishonesty, deceit, and misrepresentation); In re Strickland, 354 S.C. 169, 580 S.E.2d 126 (2003) (disbarment where attorney failed to maintain integrity of trust account and operating account, misappropriated funds, and made certain misrepresentations to disciplinary counsel).
Accordingly, we find respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants disbarment.Â  The disbarment shall be retroactive to the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension. Â Within fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing she has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender her Certificate of Admission to the Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.Â  Respondent is required to pay restitution to presently known and/or subsequently identified clients and other persons and entities who have incurred losses as a result of respondentâ€™s misconduct in connection with this matter. Â Moreover, respondent is required to reimburse the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection for any claims paid as a result of her misconduct in connection with this matter. Â Respondent will be given credit for the amount that was paid to the Lawyersâ€™ Fund which represented the funds remaining in her trust account at the time of her interim suspension. Â Respondent shall not apply for readmission until all restitution has been paid.Â  Further, within thirty (30) days of the date of this opinion, Respondent must pay the costs associated with these proceedings.

DISBARRED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Respondent was placed on interim suspension in March 2003. 
[2]In her Rule 19(c)(4) appearance, respondent admitted she was not in compliance with Rule 417. 
[3]Respondent stated she recreated ledgers for a five or six month period at the request of the Attorney to Assist; however, because she did not produce those records, the panel found her statement lacked credibility.

title: State v. Davis
description: The issue in this criminal case involves the admission of hearsay evidence under the excited utterance exception and a harmless error analysis.
text:
State v Davis


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent
v.
Christopher F. Davis, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Aiken County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26229
Heard October 18, 2006 - Filed November 20, 2006Â 

VACATED IN PART; REVERSED; AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, of Columbia, and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER:Â  We granted petitionerâ€™s request for a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision in State v. Davis, 364 S.C. 364, 613 S.E.2d 760 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  We vacate in part, reverse, and remand for a new trial.
FACTS
A jury convicted petitioner, Christopher F. Davis, of murder and armed robbery.Â  The victim was Paul Williams (â€œPaulâ€). Â On direct appeal, petitioner argued that the trial court erred by allowing Shawn Hicks, the Stateâ€™s key witness, to testify to statements made by Greg Hill.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed, finding that:Â  (1) the statements made by Hill were non-testimonial in nature, and therefore, pursuant to Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36 (2004), there was no Confrontation Clause violation; (2) the statements fit within the excited utterance exception of the hearsay rule; and (3) even if erroneously admitted, any error was harmless.
In the early morning hours of April 18, 2000, Hicks was selling crack cocaine near Paulâ€™s house in Aiken. Â Hicks testified that he heard petitioner, Reggie Stevens, and Paul arguing. Â Hicks then heard a gunshot and saw three individuals running through the victimâ€™s backyard. Â Hicks identified Stevens as one of the men because he stumbled and fell, but Hicks could not identify the other two.Â  After hearing the gunshot, Hicks sold $70 worth of crack to Stevens and Hill. Â Hicks stated he normally sold drugs to Stevens, but that $70 was an unusually large purchase.Â  Hicks testified that he believed Stevens and Hill then went to a nearby abandoned house to smoke the crack and returned shortly thereafter with petitioner.[1]Â  Petitioner had a shotgun in a black bag and a bag of coins. Â According to Hicks, petitioner bought about $30 worth of crack from Hicks with the coins. 
Additionally, Hicks testified that petitioner offered to sell him the shotgun.Â  The following colloquy occurred at trial: 

  
    
      Q.
       What, if anything, did anybody say to you to prevent you from buying [the shotgun]?
    
    
      A. 
       Well, he told me not to purchase the shotgun.
    
    
      Q.
       Who told you?
    
    
      A. 
       Greg Hill.
    
  

Although petitioner objected to the admission of Hillâ€™s statement through Hicks on the ground he could not cross-examine Hill, the trial court ruled the statement admissible as a statement by a co-conspirator.Â  Later in his direct examination, Hicks again testified to Hillâ€™s statement, as follows:

  
    
      Q. 
      [W]hat did Greg Hill tell you that night...?
    
    
      A.
       [Petitioner] and Reggie [Stevens] went in the house.
    
    
      Q. 
       All right. Did he say anything about Paul being shot or anything? Â Â 
    
    
      A.
       Yeah. Thatâ€™s why he told me not to get the shotgun.
    
    
      Q. 
       Because?
    
    
      A.
       Paul had been shot with it.
    
  

Hicks first told police about this incident when he was in jail at the Aiken County Detention Center on unrelated charges of strong armed robbery and drug distribution.Â  Petitioner and Hill were also in the detention center while Hicks was there.Â  Hicks testified that he and petitioner would write notes to each other while in jail.Â  The State admitted a note signed and dated by petitioner, but written in Hicksâ€™ handwriting.Â  Hicks read the note to the jury as follows:

Hey Chris the night that yaâ€™ll [sic] came and tried to sell me the shotgun, yaâ€™ll was [sic] coming from Paulâ€™s house and what I need to know from you who was the trigger man? Â I know it wasnâ€™t Greg from what he told me that night, so it had to be you or Reggie. Â You got the gun and Greg told you and Reggie who the one who went in the house, so who pulled the trigger? Â If Reggie did it you should write Reggieâ€™s name or if you did it, just sign your name at the bottom and Iâ€™ll help you out by writing that letter. Â Just write what you want me to tell them.

The letter is signed â€œChristopher Davisâ€ and dated â€œ3-15-01.â€[2]
Hicksâ€™ brother, Raymond â€œIkeâ€ Hicks, also testified.Â  Like his brother, Ike was out selling drugs the night of the shooting.Â  Ike stated that he heard â€œa little arguing and stuffâ€ from Paulâ€™s house and then a gunshot.Â  â€œA few minutes later, about 10, 15 - no, it was about 5 or 10 minutes later,â€ he saw a few people running from Paulâ€™s house.Â  About 10 to 20 minutes after the gunshot, Ike saw Stevens and Hill, and also saw petitioner talking to his brother.Â  Ike saw that petitioner had a gun in a bag and was asking Hicks if he wanted to buy it.Â  Ike further stated that Stevens had â€œchange and moneyâ€ and bought about $100 of crack cocaine from him in the time after Ike heard the gunshot.
Marcus White testified that petitioner came to his house late one night with a gun asking if he could keep it at Whiteâ€™s house.Â  White gave petitioner â€œsome Clorox because he said he bought it from [Stevens] and he didnâ€™t want his prints on it.â€Â  White further stated that petitioner then â€œtook the gun in the back and hid it.â€Â  He never saw petitioner come back and get the gun.Â  
Another State witness, Calvin Marcel Patten, testified that he was â€œ[h]anging out, selling dopeâ€ on the night Paul was killed.Â  Patten stated that he heard a gunshot between one and two a.m. and saw three people run from behind Paulâ€™s house.Â  According to Patten, Stevens tripped over the fence while running from the house.Â  About 15 to 30 minutes after Patten heard the gunshot, he saw petitioner.Â  
On cross-examination, Patten also testified that he spoke and exchanged notes with petitioner while they were both in jail.Â  In one written exchange, when asked by petitioner if he had been promised anything, Patten replied that he was not promised anything, â€œbut was told that I could help myself with the case by helping them withâ€ petitioner.[3]Â  From the same note, Patten read the following:

â€œYes, I talked to Shawn Hicks.Â  Some of the things he wanted me to say on the stand when we were scheduled to come to court, I couldnâ€™t say because it was a lie and I didnâ€™t see [petitioner] with a gun.Â  Some of the things he wanted me to say was that I seen [petitioner] come through the fence and also he wanted me [to] say that I seen [petitioner] with a gun and that he shot Paul.â€

Patten further testified that he saw Stevens with a pocket full of change, but he did not see a shotgun that night.Â  
In Paulâ€™s house, the police found the butt of a shotgun that had been wrapped in black electrical tape.Â  Coins were on the floor.Â  In front of Paulâ€™s house, a footprint was found in the dirt and a plaster cast was made by police; later in the investigation, the shoe print was matched to Stevensâ€™ Nike tennis shoes.Â  
At some point, petitioner, Stevens and Hill were all arrested for Paulâ€™s murder.[4]Â  Stevens told police he sold petitioner the shotgun.Â  Petitioner eventually admitted to police that he had bought the gun from Stevens, but he had thrown if off the side of a cliff.Â  The police, however, did not find the gun.
In his own defense, petitioner testified to the following.Â  On the night of the crime, he could not remember exactly where he was; he told the jury he was â€œabout 19, a teenager, just having fun and allâ€ and that he sold drugs at night.Â  He bought the gun from Stevens although he could not remember exactly when.Â  Petitioner stated that he gave Stevens $20 worth of crack for the gun which had a broken stock.Â  Petitioner decided the gun was not worth much, so he left it on the grass.Â  However, after the police told him they believed the gun had been used to murder Paul, petitioner saw Stevens who, according to petitioner, now wanted the gun back.Â  Petitioner testified that he thought Stevens â€œdone did [sic] somethingâ€ with the gun related to the murder, so petitioner wanted to get rid of the gun.Â  He threw the gun in the back of Whiteâ€™s house; then he wiped the gun down with Clorox and â€œthrew it off the cliff.â€Â  
Petitioner further testified that while he and Hicks were in jail, Hicks had promised petitioner that he (Hicks) would write a statement telling authorities that police had forced him to falsely accuse petitioner.Â  Petitioner explained that he signed his name to a blank piece of paper and only later discovered that the â€œconfessionâ€ had been written in pencil above his signature.Â  Petitioner denied killing Paul.Â  
Byron Mathis, who was in jail with petitioner, testified that he remembered Hicks and petitioner exchanging notes in jail.Â  Mathis stated that he saw petitioner sign a blank piece of paper and slid it back to Hicks.Â  Mathis testified he told petitioner â€œhe was a foolâ€ to sign a blank piece of paper. 
The jury convicted petitioner, and the trial court sentenced him to life without parole for murder, and 30 years consecutive for the armed robbery.[5]Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed.Â  Davis, supra.
ISSUE

Did the Court of Appeals err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s admission of the hearsay statement made by Hill?

DISCUSSION
Petitioner argues the statement made by Hill to Hicks that the shotgun had been used to murder Paul was erroneously admitted hearsay.Â  Petitioner further contends the error was not harmless.Â  We agree.Â  
Non-Testimonial Statement
In its opinion below, the Court of Appeals devoted an extended discussion to the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s 2004 decision in Crawford v. Washington.Â  The Court of Appeals explored the Crawford decision in depth including a discussion of scholarly articles written in the wake of Crawford.Â  In addition, the Court of Appeals analyzed numerous cases analyzing the impact of Crawford on such statements as those made:Â  (1) during 911 calls, (2) during police investigations, (3) by children, and (4) to family, friends, or acquaintances.Â  State v. Davis, 364 S.C. at 373-401, 613 S.E.2d at 765-80.Â  Ultimately, the Court of Appeals determined that Hillâ€™s statement to Hicks was non-testimonial, and therefore the rule of Crawford did not apply.Â  Given the fact that Hillâ€™s statement to Hicks clearly was made outside of an investigatory or judicial context, we agree the statement is non-testimonial.Â  However, because the overwhelming majority of the Court of Appealsâ€™ Crawford discussion does not relate to the precise issue in the instant case, we vacate that portion of the opinion.
Excited Utterance Exception to Hearsay Rule
The Court of Appeals analyzed the hearsay issue pursuant to the rule of Ohio v. Roberts, 448 U.S. 56 (1980). Â This rule allows admission of a hearsay statement if it falls within a â€œfirmly rooted hearsay exception.â€Â  Noting that the State conceded the trial court had erred by admitting the statement as a statement by a co-conspirator,[6] the Court of Appeals nevertheless agreed with the Stateâ€™s argument that the admission of Hillâ€™s statement should be upheld under the excited utterance exception.[7]Â  Davis, 364 S.C. at 402, 613 S.E.2d at 780.Â  Petitioner maintains this was error, and we agree.
An excited utterance is a â€œstatement relating to a startling event or condition made while the declarant was under the stress of excitement caused by the event or conditionâ€ and may be admitted at trial as an exception to the hearsay rule.Â  Rule 803(2), SCRE. Â The rationale underlying the excited utterance exception is that â€œthe startling event suspends the declarantâ€™s process of reflective thought, reducing the likelihood of fabrication.â€ Â State v. Dennis, 337 S.C. 275, 284, 523 S.E.2d 173, 177 (1999).Â  
A court must consider the totality of the circumstances when determining whether a statement falls within the excited utterance exception.Â  Id.Â  Nonetheless, â€œthe burden of establishing the facts which qualify a statement as an excited utterance rests with the proponent of the evidence.â€Â  31A C.J.S. Evidence Â§ 359 (1996); accord Mariano v. State, 933 So.2d 111, 118 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 2006); Jarvis v. Commonwealth, 960 S.W.2d 466 (Ky. 1998); State v. Kemp, 919 S.W.2d 278, 280 (Mo. Ct. App. 1996) (â€œThe party offering the statement as an exception to the rule against hearsay has the burden of making a sufficient showing of spontaneity to render the statement admissible.â€).Â  Finally, statements which are not based on firsthand information, such as where the declarant was not an actual witness to the event, are not admissible under the excited utterance exception to the hearsay rule. Â State v. Hill, 331 S.C. 94, 99, 501 S.E.2d 122, 125 (1998). 
As applied to the instant case, we find there simply is insufficient evidence that Hillâ€™s statement is an excited utterance. Â The Court of Appeals relied heavily on the fact that â€œmurder is certainly a startling event.â€ Â Davis, 364 SC at 404, 613 S.E.2d at 781. Â In our opinion, however, relying on the fact that there was a murder, or that the statement was about the weapon used to commit the murder, is inadequate to establish excited utterance.
In Dennis, also a murder case, we found a hearsay statement properly admitted as an excited utterance.Â  There, the State elicited the following testimony: 

  
    
      Q.
       When you saw -- Iâ€™m going to call him Moses Otis Dennis -- when you saw Moses Otis Dennis, that was real shortly after the shooting, wasn't it?
    
    
      A.
       Yes, sir.
    
    
      Q. 
       You all were still all excited and everything, werenâ€™t you?
    
    
      A.
       Yes, sir.
    
    
      Q. 
       And [Otis] told you that his brother had shot [the victim] because [the victim] had taken a swing at his brother?
    
    
      A.
      Uh huh.
    
    
      Q. 
       He said that, didnâ€™t he?
    
    
      A.
       Yes, sir.
    
  

337 S.C. at 283, 523 S.E.2d at 176-77.Â  This Court characterized Otisâ€™s statement as an excited utterance explaining that Otis, a co-defendant, â€œallegedly had just seen his brother shoot an unarmed man, abruptly ending a fistfight. Â [The witness] testified Otis made the statement to him when he saw Otis one to two minutes after the shooting, tucking a gun beneath his shirt as he walked between apartment buildings.â€ Â Id. at 284, 523 S.E.2d at 177.Â  Therefore, we held that the statement fell within a firmly rooted exception to the hearsay rule and did not violate the Confrontation Clause.Â  Id. at 288, 523 S.E.2d at 179.
Although the instant case is somewhat similar to the facts in Dennis, the cases are distinguishable.Â  First, no evidence was elicited by the State that Hill was still under the stress or excitement of Paulâ€™s shooting.Â  Therefore, the State did not meet its burden of establishing a foundation for the excited utterance.Â  See Mariano v. State, supra; Jarvis v. Commonwealth, supra; State v. Kemp, supra; see also 31A C.J.S. Evidence Â§ 359 (1996) (â€œthe burden of establishing the facts which qualify a statement as an excited utterance rests with the proponent of the evidenceâ€).
Second, the evidence in the record does not support the conclusion that Hill witnessed the shooting.Â  According to Hicks, Hill stated that Stevens and petitioner had gone into Paulâ€™s house.Â  No one testified that Hill was in the house at the time of the shooting, and Hillâ€™s statement about the gun being used to shoot Paul does not establish he witnessed the murder.[8]Â  Because there is no evidence Hill actually saw Paul get shot, Hillâ€™s statement is not admissible under the excited utterance exception to the hearsay rule.[9] Â State v. Hill, supra. Â 
Consequently, we hold Hillâ€™s statement does not fall within the excited utterance exception to the rule against hearsay.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ ruling the statement was admissible.
Harmless Error
The Court of Appeals also concluded that any error was harmless.Â  Petitioner argues, however, that because of the abysmal credibility of Hicks, the admission of Hillâ€™s statement through Hicks could not be harmless.Â  In addition, petitioner points out that another State witness, Patten, testified that Hicks had asked him to testify falsely against petitioner.Â  Given the highly circumstantial nature of the Stateâ€™s case, as well as the credibility problems of all the main witnesses, we agree with petitioner that the error was not harmless.[10]
A violation of a defendantâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to confront the witness is not per se reversible error; instead, this Court must determine whether the error was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt. Â State v. Graham, 314 S.C. 383, 386, 444 S.E.2d 525, 527 (1994); see also State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 336 S.E.2d 150 (1985) (erroneous admission of hearsay evidence subject to harmless error analysis).Â  Moreover, whether an error is harmless depends on the particular circumstances of the case. Â State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. at 573, 336 S.E.2d at 151.Â  Error is only harmless â€œwhen it â€˜could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.â€™â€Â  Id. (citation omitted).
We find the hearsay evidence admitted in the instant case almost certainly affected the result of the trial and therefore could not be harmless.Â  Hillâ€™s statement to Hicks was a crucial piece of evidence linking petitioner both to the scene of the crime and the murder weapon.Â  The scant physical evidence in this case includes a shoeprint which connected Stevens - not petitioner - to the scene.Â  Stevens was also the only person witnesses positively identified running from the scene.Â  Moreover, there are significant credibility problems with the fact witnesses (including petitioner).Â  All were involved with crack cocaine on the night in question and did not initially give informative statements to the authorities.Â  Often, cooperation with police on this investigation came only after several witnesses had been jailed on other charges and were facing prison time themselves.Â  In sum, because the hearsay statement was made by petitionerâ€™s co-defendant, the case involved mostly circumstantial evidence, and the dismal credibility of many of the witnesses, we hold the erroneous admission of Hillâ€™s statement through Hicks was not harmless.
Accordingly, we reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ finding of harmless error and remand to the trial court for a new trial.
CONCLUSION
In sum, we vacate the portion of the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion discussing Crawford v. Washington.Â  See State v. Davis, 364 S.C. at 373-401, 613 S.E.2d at 765-80.Â  Additionally, we reverse the ruling that Hillâ€™s statement to Hicks was admissible as an excited utterance exception to the hearsay rule.Â  We also reverse the finding that any error by the trial court admitting the statement was harmless.Â  The Court of Appealsâ€™ decision is therefore
VACATED IN PART; REVERSED; AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Hicks estimated his times during his testimony.Â  He stated that he saw petitioner â€œabout 5 to 10 minutesâ€ after the gunshot.Â  Therefore, according to Hicks, in five or ten minutes, he sold Stevens and Hill crack, they left to smoke the crack, and then returned with petitioner.
[2] The State presented a handwriting expert who examined the note and opined that the signature and 3-15-01 were both in petitionerâ€™s handwriting.
[3] After reading this part of the note, Patten explained as follows:Â  â€œSo basically I was told that the cases pending against me was [sic] not to worry about it because I was helping them.â€Â  
[4] Petitioner was not tried with either of his co-defendants.
[5] Petitioner was also convicted of possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent offense, but the trial court imposed no sentence for this third offense.
[6] See Rule 801(d)(2)(E) (a statement is not hearsay if it is admitted against a party and was made by a coconspirator of the party during the course and in furtherance of the conspiracy).Â  Although petitioner, Stevens, and Hill were all indicted for Paulâ€™s murder, there was no allegation or evidence of a conspiracy.
[7] The Court of Appeals addressed this argument pursuant to Rule 220(c), SCACR (â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, decision or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the Record on Appeal).
[8] In contrast, the Court of Appeals found the evidence supported â€œthe inferenceâ€ that Hill was present at the murder scene and had firsthand knowledge the shotgun had been used to kill Paul.Â  Davis, 364 S.C. at 405, 613 S.E.2d at 782.Â  The Court of Appealsâ€™ analysis, however, does not take into account Hicksâ€™ specific testimony that Hill said only Stevens and petitioner went into the house.Â  The â€œjailhouse confessionâ€ note also reinforces that Hill told Hicks only Stevens and petitioner went into Paulâ€™s house.Â  We therefore reject the Court of Appealsâ€™ conclusion that the evidence supports the inference Hill witnessed the shooting.
[9] Furthermore, because there is insufficient evidence Hill witnessed the shooting, the Stateâ€™s alternate argument that his statement was properly admitted under the present sense impression exception is without merit.Â  See Rule 803(1), SCRE (defining present sense impression as a â€œstatement describing or explaining an event or condition made while the declarant was perceiving the event or condition, or immediately thereafter.â€).
[10] We note the State contends certiorari was improvidently granted because petitioner failed to separately challenge the Court of Appealsâ€™ harmless error analysis.Â  We disagree.Â  Petitioner maintained in the petition for rehearing to the Court of Appeals, as well as in the petition for a writ of certiorari, that the error by the trial court was not harmless.Â  The argument is also made in petitionerâ€™s brief to this Court.Â  The Appellate Court Rule regarding certiorari to the Court of Appeals states that â€œ[a] question presented will be deemed to include every subsidiary question fairly comprised therein.â€Â  Rule 226(d)(2), SCACR.Â  Because petitioner specifically raised a question regarding the admission of hearsay, a harmless error argument is â€œa subsidiary question fairly comprisedâ€ within that issue.
