title: Bennett v. State
description: The issue in this PCR case involves whether the PCR court erred in finding ineffective assistance of plea counsel.
text:
Bennett v State


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Gary Wayne Bennett, Respondent
v.
State of South Carolina, Petitioner
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Horry County
Â Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26230
Submitted June 21, 2006 - Filed November 27, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott and Assistant Attorney General Julie M. Thames, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER:Â  This Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the grant of post-conviction relief (PCR) to respondent Gary Wayne Bennett.Â  Because there is no evidence in the record to show that trial counsel offered inaccurate advice to respondent or was otherwise deficient, respondent failed to meet his burden of proving counsel was ineffective.Â  Therefore, we reverse.
FACTS
On July 19, 2001, respondent pled guilty to first degree burglary, and the trial court sentenced him to 18 years imprisonment.Â  Respondent had appeared before the trial court the day before and expressed that he had some â€œdifferencesâ€ with trial counsel.Â  The trial court inquired on July 19 whether counsel and respondent had resolved those differences.Â  Counsel and respondent both responded in the negative, and respondent â€œreiterate[d]â€ to the court that he did not â€œfeel [he was] going to get a fair trialâ€ with appointed counsel.Â  He therefore asked the trial court for some time so his family could hire â€œa private lawyer.â€Â  
Noting that the offense occurred on December 25, 1999, the trial court did not grant respondent a continuance.[1]Â  Instead, the trial court asked whether he wanted to represent himself or go forward with appointed counsel.Â  Respondent did not want to proceed pro se, and he told the trial court â€œI just want the opportunity to have a paid attorney.â€Â  He explained that counsel was not â€œinterested in defendingâ€ him.Â  In response, counsel told the trial court there was another attorney who was familiar with the case, had been present at two of his meetings with respondent, and could be ready to represent respondent at trial in â€œ15 minutes time.â€Â  Respondent, however, was also not willing to have this other attorney from the Public Defenderâ€™s office represent him for trial.
At that point, the trial court gave respondent the option of one, or both, of the public defenders, or self-representation.Â  Respondent then privately spoke with his appointed counsel, and after conferring, counsel informed the trial court that respondent wanted to plead guilty.Â  On the record, respondent confirmed for the trial court his desire to enter a guilty plea.
The trial court went over the indictment for first degree burglary, explained that this felony is considered a violent, most serious offense, and informed respondent that it â€œcarries anywhere from 15 years to life.â€Â  When the trial court separately asked respondent if he understood the charge and the possible punishment, respondent replied in the affirmative.Â  After pleading guilty, the trial court then went over the constitutional rights respondent was waiving, including the right to a jury trial.Â  The trial court specifically asked respondent if he was satisfied with counselâ€™s â€œadvice about this plea,â€ and respondent said yes.[2]
The State explained to the trial court the facts surrounding the offense. Respondent and his then-girlfriend, Amber Vrooman, had entered the victimâ€™s vacation condominium in Surfside Beach during the nighttime hours; respondent had access to the condo because he worked a pest control job.Â  The pair took a television, a vacuum cleaner, and a VCR.Â  Vrooman was also charged in the case.Â  According to the State, Vrooman had been the person who informed police about the case after she and respondent had an â€œaltercationâ€ and she was willing to testify as a Stateâ€™s witness to the facts of the crime.Â  The trial court sentenced respondent to 18 years.
Respondent did not appeal, but he filed for PCR.Â  In his PCR application, respondent alleged ineffective assistance of counsel and that his Sixth Amendment right to â€œcounsel of choiceâ€ had been revoked.Â  
At the PCR hearing, respondent testified that he first met with counsel in September 2000 for his bond hearing and then did not meet with him again until January 2001.[3] Â In June 2001, respondent again met with counsel, and, according to respondent, counsel told him he could get him 15 years in a plea bargain with the solicitor.Â  Respondent testified he told counsel he did not want to plead guilty because he had not committed first degree burglary; according to respondentâ€™s PCR testimony, he was not in the condo in the nighttime, but rather was there at eight in the morning.Â  Significantly, respondent further testified that counsel told him if he went to trial and was found guilty, the trial judge would sentence him to life imprisonment.
The PCR court found:Â  (1) respondent had not knowingly and intelligently waived his right to a direct appeal; and (2) counsel was ineffective.Â  The PCR court granted respondent a new trial.
ISSUE[4]

Did the PCR court err in granting respondent a new trial based on ineffective assistance of counsel?

DISCUSSION
The State argues the PCR court erred in finding that respondentâ€™s trial counsel was ineffective in advising respondent to plead guilty.Â  We agree.
There is a two-prong test for evaluating claims of ineffective assistance of counsel. Â The first prong of the test requires that a defendant show that his counselâ€™s performance was deficient such that it falls below an objective standard of reasonableness.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984); Alexander v. State, 303 S.C. 539, 402 S.E.2d 484 (1991). Â The second part of the test requires a defendant to show there is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s unprofessional errors, the result of the proceeding would have been different.Â  Id.Â  Where there has been a guilty plea, the applicant must prove prejudice by showing that, but for counselâ€™s errors, there is a reasonable probability he would not have pleaded guilty and instead would have insisted on going to trial. Â Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52 (1985); Alexander v. State, supra.Â  Furthermore, â€œ[a] defendant who pleads guilty upon the advice of counsel may only attack the voluntary and intelligent character of the guilty plea by showing the advice he received from counsel was not within the range of competence demanded of attorneys in criminal cases.â€ Â Richardson v. State, 310 S.C. 360, 363, 426 S.E.2d 795, 797 (1993). 
In determining guilty plea issues, it is proper to consider the guilty plea transcript as well as evidence at the PCR hearing. Â Harres v. Leeke, 282 S.C. 131, 318 S.E.2d 360 (1984).Â  This Court will uphold the findings of the PCR judge when there is any evidence of probative value to support them.Â  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 386 S.E.2d 624 (1989). Â The Court, however, will not uphold the findings when there is no probative evidence to support them. Holland v. State, 322 S.C. 111, 470 S.E.2d 378 (1996).
We find the PCR court erred in finding that counsel was deficient.Â  Both the plea transcript and respondentâ€™s testimony at the PCR hearing clearly indicate that counsel did consult with respondent and advised him that he should enter a guilty plea.Â  Taking respondentâ€™s version of events, counsel specifically stated that if respondent went to trial and a jury found him guilty, he would get a life sentence.[5]Â  Thus, counsel advised respondent to plead guilty based, at least in part, on the likelihood of what counsel believed the sentence would be.Â  We find that this is not an inappropriate concern for counsel to communicate to his client.Â  Cf. Wade v. State, 698 S.W.2d 621, 623 (Mo. Ct. App. 1985) (where appellant claimed his guilty plea was not voluntary because counsel told him he would receive a life sentence if he went to trial, the court rejected the claim, stating that â€œ[c]ounsel should discuss with clients the potential results of trial, and life imprisonment was a possible sentence on both chargesâ€ against appellant). Â 
Indeed, counselâ€™s advice that respondent would have gotten a life sentence was not technically incorrect because life is the maximum sentence for first degree burglary.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311(B) (2003) (first degree burglary â€œis a felony punishable by life imprisonmentâ€); see also Carter v. State, 329 S.C. 355, 361, 495 S.E.2d 773, 776 (1998) (where counselâ€™s advice regarding possible maximum sentence was correct, the Court held that counselâ€™s performance was not deficient or ineffective); Wade v. State, 698 S.W.2d at 623 (counsel should discuss the potential results of trial with clients).[6]
Moreover, while respondent certainly subjectively believed that counsel was unprepared for trial, respondentâ€™s own testimony at the PCR hearing also established that the two primary fact witnesses at trial would have been him and Vrooman.Â  Because any trial would essentially be respondentâ€™s word against Vroomanâ€™s, there can be no claim that counsel should have further investigated the case to discover other evidence or witnesses.Â  Finally, it is evident from the plea transcript that counsel was willing to go to trial, or would have allowed his associate from the Public Defenderâ€™s office to try the case, but respondent obviously wanted a privately retained attorney.
Respondent simply did not meet his burden of proving the first prong of the Strickland test.Â  E.g., Bannister v. State, 333 S.C. 298, 509 S.E.2d 807 (1998) (the applicant has the burden of proving the allegations of the PCR petition).Â  In order for respondent to get relief, he must demonstrate it was because of counselâ€™s deficiency that he was induced to plead guilty.Â  What respondent did prove, however, is the following:Â  (1) he wanted to go to trial, but only with a private attorney; (2) the trial court did not grant him a continuance to allow his family more time to hire a private attorney; and (3) after conferring with counsel, he decided to enter a guilty plea.Â  It appears that respondentâ€™s real argument on PCR is that the trial court should have granted respondentâ€™s request for a continuance to enable him to retain private counsel.Â  Trial error, however, â€œdoes not constitute an appropriate basis for a finding of ineffective assistance of counsel.â€ Â Wolfe v. State, 326 S.C. 158, 162 n.2, 485 S.E.2d 367, 369 n.2 (1997); cf. Richardson v. State, supra (where a defendant pleads guilty, he may only attack the voluntary and intelligent character of the guilty plea by showing the advice he received from counsel was not competent).Â  Here, although the PCR court did find respondent was entitled to a belated appeal, respondent did not request review of that finding from this Court. Â See Rule 227(i)(1), SCACR. Therefore, respondent has abandoned any direct appeal issues.
We hold there is no probative evidence in the record that counsel deficiently advised respondent to plead guilty; accordingly, we reverse the PCR courtâ€™s grant of a new trial.Â  See Holland v. State, supra (this Court will not uphold the findings of the PCR court when there is no evidence of probative value to support them).Â  
 REVERSED.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Actually, respondent was not arrested until July 2000; nonetheless, he had been incarcerated for over one year by the time of the plea.
[2] Additionally, when the trial court made its on-the-record finding that respondentâ€™s plea was â€œfreely, voluntarily, and intelligently made,â€ the trial court specifically noted that although respondent had â€œsome disagreementsâ€ with counsel, respondent was â€œsatisfied with [counselâ€™s] advice concerning this plea.â€
[3]  At this time, respondent also had a pending murder charge, and respondent testified that they discussed matters related to the murder charge but did not discuss the first degree burglary charge at issue in the instant case.Â  
[4] We note there is no belated direct appeal issue before the Court because respondent did not file for review as required by the Appellate Court Rules.Â  See Rule 227(i)(1), SCACR (when the PCR court has affirmatively found that the right to a direct appeal was not knowingly and intelligently waived, a petition for a writ of certiorari shall contain a question raising this issue; in addition, a brief addressing the direct appeal issues shall be served and filed); Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 291 n.1, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986) (even where the PCR court makes a finding that the right to a direct appeal was not knowingly and intelligently waived, the PCR court â€œmay not grant relief on this basis;â€ instead, the PCR applicant must petition this Court for review).
[5] Counsel testified at the PCR hearing that respondent never told him the burglary did not occur in the nighttime and that Vrooman was ready to take the witness stand for the State on the day respondent entered his plea.Â  Finally, counsel testified that he thought it was in respondentâ€™s best interest to plead guilty because if respondent went to trial and was convicted, he would not have been surprised at a life sentence.Â  According to counsel, he told respondent that the trial court â€œmay very wellâ€ sentence him to life imprisonment if he went to trial; counsel denied telling respondent that the trial court would sentence him to life.Â  The PCR court, however, obviously believed respondentâ€™s testimony because it specifically found counsel told respondent that if he was convicted, he would be given a life sentence by the trial judge.Â  That determination is entitled to deference.Â  Solomon v. State, 313 S.C. 526, 529, 443 S.E.2d 540, 542 (the Court gives great deference to a PCR courtâ€™s findings when matters of credibility are involved).
[6] Regardless, even where counsel offers misinformation, this deficiency can be cured where the trial court properly informs the defendant about the sentencing range.Â  See Wolfe v. State, 326 S.C. 158, 485 S.E.2d 367 (1997) (even if counsel gives erroneous advice, an applicant is not entitled to PCR where any misconceptions are cured by the colloquy during the guilty plea proceeding); Burnett v. State, 352 S.C. 589, 576 S.E.2d 144 (2003) (any possible misconceptions on PCR applicantâ€™s part were cured by the colloquy during the plea proceeding); see also Moorehead v. State, 329 S.C. 329, 333, 496 S.E.2d 415, 416 (1998) (â€œthe transcript of the guilty plea hearing will be considered to determine whether any possible error by counsel was cured by the information conveyed at the plea hearingâ€).Â  Here, the trial court clearly told respondent that the sentence for first degree burglary â€œcarries anywhere from 15 years to life.â€Â  (Emphasis added).

title: James v. Horace Mann Insurance Company
description: Respondents filed this action against Appellant, alleging bad faith in handling an insurance claim.  A jury awarded Respondents $146,600 actual damages and $1,000,000 punitive damages.  This Court affirmed.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Russell James and Teresa James, Respondents,
v.
Horace Mann Insurance Company, James D. Geiger, and Ronald Wilson,
Defendants,
of whom Horace Mann Insurance Company is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â John L. Breeden, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26231 Â Â 
Heard November 1, 2006 - Filed November 27, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Lawrence B. Orr, of Orr, Elmore & Ervin, LLC, of Florence, for Appellant.
Kevin M. Barth, of Ballenger, Barth & Hoefer, of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  In this action, a jury found Horace Mann Insurance Company (Appellant) liable for bad faith related to the handling of an insurance claim and awarded actual and punitive damages to Russell and Teresa James (Respondents).Â  Appellant appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of its motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV), new trial, or new trial nisi remittitur as to punitive damages.Â  Appellant also appeals the trial courtâ€™s admission of evidence regarding Respondentsâ€™ lost wages and attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  We certified the case for review from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and we affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In the early 1980s, Respondents purchased a homeownerâ€™s insurance policy from Appellant through its agent, Ronald Wilson.Â  In 2000, Appellant sent a renewal notice to Respondents which included a new endorsement for liability coverage for animal bites.Â  The endorsement provided coverage for liability arising out of animal bites, with several exclusions, and limited the coverage to $25,000 per occurrence.Â  Respondents renewed their homeownerâ€™s insurance policy, including the animal bite liability coverage, in 2000, 2001, and 2002.Â  
On August 2, 2002, James D. Geiger was bitten by Respondentsâ€™ dog and was hospitalized due to injuries arising out of the bite.Â  Respondents subsequently submitted a claim to Appellant under their homeownerâ€™s insurance policy to cover Geigerâ€™s damages.Â  Appellant assigned the matter to a claims adjuster, Bruce Garner (Adjuster).Â  On August 16, 2002, Adjuster contacted Geiger and told Geiger that there was a medical payments coverage, which was immediately payable.Â  Adjuster also told Geiger that Respondents had liability coverage for animal bites up to $25,000, but denied Geiger could collect under that coverage without further proof.Â  
Geiger hired an attorney and sued Respondents for damages arising out of the dog bite.Â  Settlement negotiations failed and the case went to trial.Â  South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 47-3-110 (1987) imposes strict liability on a dog owner for damages arising out of a dog bite when the victim is lawfully on the ownerâ€™s property, except when the victim provokes the dog.Â  A jury returned a verdict against Respondents and awarded Geiger $50,500 in damages. Â Appellant paid $25,000 of the judgment and Respondents paid the remaining $25,500.
Respondents filed this action against Appellant and Wilson[1] alleging seven causes of action including, inter alia, a declaratory judgment to determine the liability coverage under their homeownerâ€™s insurance policy for injuries arising out of a dog bite, breach of contract, negligence, and bad faith.Â  At trial, Respondents testified when they submitted Geigerâ€™s claim to Appellant, they believed the applicable coverage under their homeownerâ€™s insurance policy was the general personal liability coverage.Â  Respondents testified that prior to submitting Geigerâ€™s claim they were unaware their homeownerâ€™s insurance policy included a specific coverage for liability arising out of animal bites.Â  Respondents also testified Wilson never advised them of this liability coverage for animal bites. 
Geiger testified Adjuster told him that under Respondentsâ€™ homeowner insurance policy, Geiger must prove negligence to recover any amount beyond the medical payments coverage.Â  Geiger also testified he would have accepted a settlement offer prior to hiring an attorney and he would not have hired an attorney if Adjuster had told him the correct law and agreed to cover his medical bills and lost wages.Â  Geigerâ€™s attorney and Respondent Russell James also testified Adjuster took the position that Geiger must prove negligence before he could recover from Respondents.Â  Adjuster testified Geiger had to prove he did not provoke the dog to recover damages from Respondents.Â  
Respondent Russell James testified he believed Adjuster, and thus Appellant, had mishandled the insurance claim by refusing to pay Geigerâ€™s medical bills and lost wages without proof of Respondentsâ€™ negligence.Â  He further testified he felt Appellant had mishandled the claim by encouraging Geiger to sue Respondents.
